author: brandonforty2

description.text:
In almost a year using a 3d printer, I have learned that platform calibration is probably the most important factor to get nice prints.
This "method" uses a digital depth meter, a webcam, a macro, a spreadsheet app and a OCR application to get a matrix of the current heights in the platform. My adjustment will be based on a primitive approach (almost by hand).

1) Print http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14174 (or similar) for your digital gauge 2) Set a webcam (or better link your meter via serial port) to look into the meter screen, in this case with http://www.webcamlaboratory.com is easy to do an OCR and get the data (too bad that app is now exclusive for Intel learning pcs) 3) Use the attached macro in Vtask (or use your prefered macro app, or better direct link with the printer via serial). The macro should do this: http://screencast.com/t/6SduKMZ5Q 4) Use the attached excel and replace your values. Of course the "stress" deformations per screw are very dumb values I guessed by hand, no 2D interpolation or something fancy (I am not sure yet how the platform bends, so it maybe much harder than I guess, but I just wanted a quick test to help me) 5) Rinse and repeat! until the flatness on your platform is TOO DAMN HIGH! PS: In my excel graph, height is dramatized (all values are less than 0,3 mm, so my platform is quite flat) Here is a video :)
http://youtu.be/yjfENofvFaM

comments.text: Does your macros interface with the printer? It doesn't sound like it, so here's a suggestions: what if you told the printer to move to each corner/screw location, then home Z and read the "depth," record it, repeat for all screws. Then suggest amount of change per screw?

title: Hypercube Evolution Chimera mount with inductive sensor

description.text: I couldn't find a Chimera mount on Thingiverse that functioned correctly with the normal 300x300 dimensions of the Hypercube Evolution in combination with the standard inductive sensor supplied by Lin. I placed the Inductive mount within the boundaries of the x carriage so it wont hit against the z rails. This made the structure a little weak so I reinforced it with some extra plastic on top. I also sacrificed one of the mounting holes of the fanduct, but it don't seem to be needed for support. Modified fanduct is also included. Fanduct is not the prettiest of models but it prints correctly. Make sure the cables for the heater elements don't hit into your Z rail holder and tie everything up nice and tight.

author: JNJLabbe

description.text:
Angry Strahd bust for my Curse of Strahd for players. My gift to them for 2 years worth of adventure! Something for their mantelpieces to remind them of that time they pissed off a vampire lord

Started with mz4250's Strahd for the armor (https://www.shapeways.com/product/JVKEV4E3P/strahd-von-zarovich), melded it with the Dawngaurd and began adding more and more detail... Might retouch some day for more accurate detail.

This project documents how I made a 3D printed strobe for my Paramotor. The strobe is designed specifically for a Bulldog Paramotor, so the design would have to be altered to suit a different type of Paramotor. Therefore this project is aimed mainly towards Bulldog Paramotor owners.

I have installed the strobe on my paramotor and I'm really pleased with the outcome. The strobe outputs about 53 flashes per minute with over 8 hours continuous running from a fully charged battery. When the battery needs charging, you just quick release the battery/electronics box from its caddy and charging is done via a micro USB port. The internal battery takes about 6hrs to charge.

All this began in 2017 when I was experimenting with Arduino electronics and wanting to build my own strobe. I needed something that was professional and functional, so I began by learning google sketchup, thanks to Paul McWhorter video tutorials "3D printing from sketchup", see - https://youtu.be/SZnu3GzXZ-g. My first 3D design was the strobe which was a huge learning curve and took many hours as I was learning along the way.

Once I was happy with the software and my first design I ordered a Prusa i3 Mk2S 3D printer kit. It took about a week of evenings to build the printer before I could printi my first version of the Strobe. As you can see from this video, I'm well chuffed - https://youtu.be/6y2r8-kYxwo

I have invested a lot of time and money into this project and gained masses of knowledge, from learning how to design and 3D print and some new found electronics knowledge from Paramotor friend Simon Walker. After multiple versions of design and print iterations, taking over 100hrs of printing different designs until perfection, I'm now happy with the final product!

People keep asking me if I will sell the strobe. I'm not looking to setup a production line as each unit takes many hours to print and assemble. Therefore I'm making this project open source for anyone who would like to take on the task themselves. However If you would prefer to purchase one fully assembled then I offer a purchase price of £150.

If you make one, please share it with this thingy project.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

25%

Introduction

I started this project as I wanted to create my own Paramotor Strobe specifically designed for a Bulldog Paramotor. The strobe needed to meet the following criteria:-

  1. Lightweight
  2. Must be integrated within the outer hoop, this is important as most strobes are fixed to the outer hoop and can get in the way of the lines when launching or landing.
  3. Easy to disconnect the battery for charging
  4. At least 6 hours continuous running before recharging

The design has 4 main components:-

  1. The strobe
  2. Electronics and battery box
  3. Caddy to hold the electronics and battery
  4. Extension lead to connect the strobe and electronics

Details for each of the components can be found below. I will detail each seperatly.

The Bulldog Paramotor - With the Strobe and Electronics The Strobe - Requirements

Items Required:-

1 x Bulldog Strobe (See thing file - Item01_The_Bulldog_Strobe.stl)
4 x Bulldog Strobe LED Cover (See thing file - Item02_The_Bulldog_Strobe_LED_Cover.stl)
1 x XT30 Cover (See thing file - Item04_XT30_Cover_B.stl)
(The above items are 3D printed with 1.75mm Transparent PLA at resolution 0.3mm and 25% infill)

The remaining non-3D printed items:-

4 x 9-12v 10W LEDs (See Strobe_Example.jpg)
1 x XT30 Female connector
650mm 6A Automotive DC Power Cable - Twin Core Figure '8' 12V Black/Red
500mm Heat Shrink (Size: 6.4mm)
450mm Braided Sleeving - (Inner Diameter (Bundle Size): 5mm (3-9mm) )
1 x small cable tie (160mm long and 2.6mm wide)
Gorilla Glue Gorilla 25ml
Superglue ( Cyanoacrylate )

Tools:-
Soldering Iron and Solder
Wire Cutters
Wire Strippers
Small wooden skewers for mixing epoxy.
Disposable piece of plastic for mixing epoxy on.

The Bulldog Paramotor Strobe The Strobe - Instructions

Using superglue, bond each of the 4 LEDs each face on the 3D printed Paramotor Strobe (thing file - Item01). Insure that the polarity + is positioned the same direction on each face, I prefer to have the Positive terminals nearest the cable entry side of the Strobe. Also be sure to check each of the 4 LEDs are working before you superglue them on to the 3d printed strobe faces.

Prepare the 6A 12V twin core cable. You will need to strip back the outer insulation enough to feed through to each of the 4 LEDs. Solder each of the LEDs in PARALLEL, red wire to each + LED Terminal and Black wire to each - LED Terminal. You need to pass the wire tightly through the channels to ensure the wiring remains within the strobe body. This is to allow sufficient room for the 3D printed LED covers. Once all the terminals are soldered check that the LED faces can be clicked into place, then remove each one and prepare the 2 part epoxy, you need to mix enough to not only glue the covers, but also to insure they are water tight.
OPTIONAL - You can optionally add the braided sleeve and heat shrink to the 2 core cable. If you do this, it needs to be prepared before you solder it to the LEDs, this is so you can pull through the heat shrink into the cable entry hole on the strobe.

Once the Strobe has been wired and glued, last step is soldering the Female XT30 connector. Be sure to use the XT30 3D printed cover (Item04), slide this onto the cable behind the XT30 connector. Once soldered, you slide the cover over the XT30 connector, I use a couple of dabs of superglue to insure it remains fixed.

XT30 Connector and 3D Printed XT30 covers Electronics and Battery - Requirements

Electronics box before assembly Electronics and Battery - Instructions

First things first I had to program the Digispark Attiny85 board before installing it in the electronics box. I used Arduino 1.8.5 with Digispark Programmer - Micronucleus installed and the script in thing files called "Digispark_Paramotor_Strobe.ino"

Now on to the wiring, a picture speaks a thousand words, so I have included pictures and diagrams you can follow - https://flic.kr/s/aHsmgrAgkg

NOTE - I adjusted the Buck Converter to 14 volts.

Completed Wiring of Electronics Box The Caddy - Requirements

Item16_Strobe_Electronics_Caddy_Bottom.stl
Item17_Strobe_Electronics_Caddy_Top.stl
(The above 2 items are 3D printed with 1.75mm Transparent PLA at resolution 0.3mm and 25% infill)

The remaining non-3D printed items:-
White Velcro loop (non sticky back) Length=250mm Width=25mm
White Velcro hook (single sided sticky tape backing) Length=90mm Width=25mm
White Velcro hook (single sided sticky tape backing) Length=25mm Width=25mm
2x Cable Ties - 200mm long 5mm wide

The Caddy - Instructions

Feed the white 250mm length velcro loop(soft) through the velcro channel so that the caddy lid is fastened to the caddy body.

Stick the 90mm velcro hook to the outside of the velcro channel on the caddy case bottom. Optionally stick the 25mm velcro hook to the caddy case lid.

Place the 2 cable ties through the cable tie entry slots and strap the strobe caddy to the paramotor frame. I used a single wrap of electrical insulation tape around the frame where the caddy is positioned to stop the caddy sliding.

Caddy container for electronics - velcro added Caddy container for electronics - cable ties added Extension lead to connect the strobe and electronics

The purpose of the extension lead is to permantly place it on the Paramotor frame. This allows easy disconnection of the electronics case for charging. Also, if you dismantle the Paramotor, it enables disconnection from the Strobe which is placed on the cage spar.

You will need:-
570mm 6A Automotive DC Power Cable - Twin Core Figure '8' 12V Black/Red
560mm Heat Shrink (Size: 6.4mm)
510mm Braided Sleeving - (Inner Diameter (Bundle Size): 5mm (3-9mm) )
1 x XT30 Male connector
1 x XT30 Female connector
1 x XT30 3D printed Cover (See thing file - Item03_XT30_Cover_A.stl)
1 x XT30 3D printed Cover (See thing file - Item04_XT30_Cover_B.stl)

Just wire up the XT30s plugs and secure the cable to the Paramotor frame.

Overview

I have been flying paramotor since 2011. Last year (2017) I had a flight during the 30mins after Sunset and I felt vulnerable. This is what prompted me to start this Paramotor Strobe project.

Inspiration

This is not a lesson, but I have included as much info as possible for someone to build the same or get inspiration for a similar project.

Items Required:-

comments.text: Glad to see others working on redesigning stupidly expensive PPG gear. On my workbench in some state of completion I've been working to copy the skyflar. I've got a couple versions in built states as I was exploring using single die low voltage high amp led (like CREE), but think I've settled for using (5) 10W multi-die chip led similar to yourself. I was debating adding a LED current balancer chip in my design (http://www.ti.com/product/LM3466), all depends on how you are powering it. It may not be needed at all. Further testing is needed.

description.text:
This is a replacement blade stop for the red handled Craftsman Utility Cutter. This design is a direct replacement I created. My bottom layer gives me decent results, so I printed it with the blade stop side down, and a 2.4 mm thick bottom layer.

In the picture with 3 of the stops shown, the top one was printed with supports and the bottom one printed with no supports (note the back hole isn't as sharp). The black stop in the middle is the original from the tool.

Seems to work well so far, and at 40 min to print with a cost of $0.10 + electricity, I think this will work long enough for the time and money invested.

Please feel free to contact me for any design changes or questions (i.e. smooth out the sides for an easier print since the design was just to copy the original, not for fitment issues).

To install and remove, leave the knife locked in the close position while you unscrew the screws for removal AND when you tighten the screws during install.

print_settings.Resolution:: anything, but for crankshaft 0.1 mm is recommended
print_settings.Notes:: The large spindle is the only part that needs support in printing.

description.text:
Printed in PLA, this motor can deliver up to 1.6 Nm (yes, 1.6 Newton meter or 160 Ncm) at 4 bar pressure. Forget all those other designs that can hardly lift a few grams, the real work starts here. See video how it lifts 5+ kg using a 60mm diameter spindle. Without gearbox.

The mechanical design is more or less identical to that of the Bourke engine, which was developed in the 1920s. The only difference is in the gas: here, pressurized air is used instead of fuel combustion.

The engine acts as a rotational stepper motor with step size 90 degrees, so it needs two 5/2-way valves (or equivalent) for control.

Video with assembly instructions: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I9DUlbN97yk

Enjoy making this thing, and feel free to ask for help if you need to!

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

anything, but for crankshaft 0.1 mm is recommended

Infill:

high / solid

Notes:

To survive 4+ bar of pressure and deliver 1.6 Nm of torque, solid infill is recommended (especially for the crankshaft). Solid housing also helps making it airtight. Watch out for overextrusion at 100% infill, as this would affect dimensional accuracy.

The large spindle is the only part that needs support in printing.

Applications and assembly instructions, music by Tim de Man Assembly instructions

Grind parts until mechanics slide smoothly and clearances between middle and top/bottom housing parts are minimal.
Put four piston plates on the crankshaft. Twist two of them and put piston heads on each side, properly aligned. If the tight fit holes are too small, file the pins and/or holes until it fits; if it is too loose, use glue.
Cut four seals using cutting tool, from about 1mm thick silicone rubber sheet or equivalent.
Drill four air inlets in bottom housing and push pneumatic tubes all way through. If loose: use glue (e.g. Loctite 770+406).
Tap M4 threads in remaining 28 holes in bottom housing.
Optional: apply impregnating agent to make housing airtight (e.g. "waterdichtmaken.nl"). Not really needed if housing is printed solid and/or some leakage is acceptable.
Apply blue silicone on middle housing and (optional) vaseline grease on pistons and crankshaft.
Place crankshaft with pistons in housing. Put seals adjacent to each piston head. Important: large face of seal must face outwards, i.e. towards the pneumatic tubes!
Assemble motor and tighten with M4 screws.
Connect tubes to two 5/2-way valves, and test!
Two spindles are provided, with radius 30mm and 55mm respectively. Use screw(s) in holes to secure it to the shaft.

Crankshaft and pistons Additional materials and tools

Silicone rubber sheet, around 1mm thick
4mm (outer diameter) pneumatic tubes, e.g. polyurethane tubes or Lego pneumatic tubes
M4 x 30mm bolts (28 pieces)
M4 tap (or use M4 nuts, washers and longer bolts)
Sealant such as blue silicone
(Optional) Lubricant such as vaseline (petroleum jelly)
(Optional) Something to make 3D printed parts airtight, impregnating agent "waterdichtmaken.nl" works fine
Stanley knife with 9mm blade size
Drill with right size for tightly fitting tubes (3.8mm works well for 4mm polyurethane tubes)
Compressor
Valves (two 5/2-way valves or equivalent)
(Optional) M3 tap and screws with sharp tip, to secure spindle to shaft
(Optional) M6 screws to mount motor on mounting bracket

Inside view Some math

Cylinder cross-sectional area is 30 mm x 20 mm = 600 mm^2. Stroke size is 16 mm. Crank throw is 8 mm (on rounded side of crank, slightly lower on flatted side).

Theoretical piston force at at 4 bar = 0.4 MPa pressure: F = P A = 0.410^6 Pa 60010^-6 m^2 = 240 N
Theoretical torque: M = F r = 240 N * 0.008 m = 1.9 Nm
Effective torque is a bit lower due to friction, but still around 1.5Nm

Troubleshooting

Friction and leakage are the main enemies of any rapid prototyped pneumatic device. It is impossible to fully eliminate both of them, but they can be kept to a minimum by good manufacturing and troubleshooting.

Friction
  • Check rigid parts: operate crankshaft by hand to feel resistance. Find friction surfaces and grind them, or adjust printer settings (finer detail, lower extrusion etc). The motor is quite powerful, so a small amount of resistance is no problem.
  • Check seal dimensions. Ideally, 0.2-0.3 mm larger than cavity width and height. The cutter is designed to cut 30.3 x 20.2 mm seals. If too large: reduce seal cutting block dimension (set at 99.5% etc).
  • Sealant (blue silicone or equivalent) could add excessive friction if not wiped out of the cylinder. Always operate pneumatic gripper a few times at low pressure to clean cylinder walls using the seal. Leftover sealant collected by the seal is normally no problem.
Leakage
  • Through housing: 3D printed parts are usually porous. Solutions: a) print really 100% solid (at the edge of overextrusion), b) apply imprenating agent such as "waterdichtmaken.nl" for PLA or a dilute ABS+acetone mix for ABS parts, c) any other stuff that fills up the pores (paint? nail varnish? ...)
  • Through/along top and bottom cover: if first layer not printed 100% solid, channels will be present along which air can escape. Solution: overextrude first layer, either by extrusion factor or by re-calibrating z offset (lower nozzle). Side-effect: elephant feet. Other solution: fill up channels with stuff.
  • Along walls: too low resolution (e.g. 0.3mm) gives ribbed walls which cannot be sealed off effectively with the seal.
  • Along seals: check seal dimensions, should be at least 0.2mm larger than cavity. If too small: scale seal cut block up by 0.5% or so.
  • Between housing parts: seal off with sealant such as blue silicone; tighten screws.
  • Between housing and air tube: irregular hole or too large hole, or too stiff tube. Solutions: a) use sealant, b) glue tube to housing with e.g. Loctite 770+406.
  • If one chamber causes excessive leakage, then its seal might have been inserted the wrong way round.
  • Seals made from a bicycle tyre's inner tube might be curled, causing problems in sealing
  • Too thin or too flexible seals are also ineffective, experiment with different rubber materials

title: Battlefleet Gothic Weapons & Bits
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A collection of all the doodads that go in weapon & turret mounts, finally in one place! Everything guaranteed to be usable with all ships, with the exception of Chaos Light Cruiser's Prow mount which will probably look good with only things labelled 'Chaos Mount'

All bits have been touched up and are recommended over the original uploads.
-Most weapon barrels are bigger, longer, or are more print-friendly.
-Weapon batteries have bigger detail & the above-mentioned barrel upgrade.
-All launch bays had some details thickened and some embarrassing holes fixed.
-All sensor doodads are thicker, there are also 2 sizes of sensor mast.
-Separated the lance turret from the Start Fort & gave it a centering pin for standard weapon mounts and a mount for the Chaos Light Cruiser prow.
-There are small-size laser batteries now.
-Added a smaller version of the Raiders prow turret.

Any similar bits or doodads will in the future find a home here so this may be updated randomly.

remixed_from.title: Filament dry box for 3-4 spools of filament

title: Drybox passthrough for 1/8 NPT/M10 and M6 Bowden/PTFE fitting

description.text:
I got inspired by the passthrough part, but was missing the option for having a bowden fitting placed in the passthough - and a cap, that could be mounted with the bowden fitting sitting inside the cap.
This is what I came up with.

The printer need to be good calibrated in order for the threads to be printed in the right dimensions. Make sure, that extruder e-steps and extrusion multiplier is set correctly.

Early version of the files had the thread for the cap as M14x1.0 - this has been changed in the current version to M14x1.5, as this is easier to print and to mount afterwards.

These are the fittings, that I use in my model. They are often labeled as M10, but usually it is 1/8 NPT thread (I found M10 thread to be a bit loose).

author: hOTmOLd

description.text:
This is a remix of the Terrapin Bijou Sidewinder 6x4.5 Pinhole Camera shown here with the Incher pinhole lens. Primarily, I performed small modifications to the body to remove branding and allow for customization using fabric, adhesive film, or other materials for the body.

Small modifications have been performed to the dimensions to print more easily (reductions of overhangs and difficult to print areas, and some cleanup of the geometry). The film counter window on the back has been simplified, and is intended to be covered with a resealable, non-light transmissive tape, such several layers of gaffers tape. This inherently introduces a light leak when in use, so it may be helpful to practice winding before loading film with an old 120 paper backing, and become familiar with winding prior to shooting.

I was unable to find screw hardware which adequately allowed attaching the lid using nuts as the design was intended. I resolved this by filling the screw holes with glue, drilling, and self tapping the holes with a machine screw. If possible, it may be better to use a brass insert. If I perform a redesign of the camera, I'll take this approach.

The STL files for the large film wind knobs, and internal parts for the body can be found on the Terrapin Bijou Sidewinder page. No modifications have been made to these parts.

title: Top Spool Holder for Delta and Kossel

description.text:
This is a central spool holder for 200mm bed class delta 3d printers. It requires a 5" x 5/8Dia central lag bolt, two 608 bearings, and four 5/8" nuts. This holds the spool centrally to help weight the machine down, keep the center of gravity in the middle, and feed your extruder in a simple path.

if starting from nothing, print one of the "top spool holder", two "spoolholder uni", and one or more of the filament holders to facilitate your filament path. This should result in an extremely smooth and even feed of filament. Hope you like it.

When printing the spool holder you will need some good overhang performance if you want tp print without support. my Anet A8 was able to do decently well with the sloped structure without any support, but it has rather good part cooling.

author: zakatakk

print_settings.Notes:: THE TOOL IS STILL UNDER CONSTRUCTION, BUT YOU MAY CONSIDER IT FOR YOUR INSPIRATION.

title: Tool to replace LEDs in a LED Cube (concept phase)

description.text:
Unfortunately I broke some LEDs in my 3D LED cube (see https://sites.google.com/view/flips-cubicle/home for details to the cube). The LED cube is made out of blocks, so it is hardly possible to hold an LED during replacement.

I developed a tool which holds an LED during unsoldering and keeps holding it when picking it out of the cube. To bring the new LED to the correct position, the tool picks two or more other LEDs to hold the new LED at the correct position.

The tool consistk of a frame with two independent sliders in it. On top of the slider are pickers for LEDs: One half of each picker is fixed to the trame, the other half is moved by either slider. The sliders end in a handle, there is also a spring for each slider. The tool can be disassembled for changing the positions of the pickers and their assignments to the sliders. (As long as the springs are inserted, the sliders can not be disassembled. Once you remove the springs, you can disassemble and rearrange the sliders and the pickers.)

The design is done in OpenScape, mostly configurable using design parameters (LED grid size, LED dimensions, tolerances, other dimensions, ...). It can be splitted into smaller parts which can be printed (the final tool will have 30cm length, my print bed is 20cm.) At the splitting points, flats are provided for glueing. The flat parts are not part of the actual tool, but I designed them to align and position the splitted parts during glueing.

THE TOOL IS STILL UNDER CONSTRUCTION, BUT YOU MAY USE IT FOR INSPIRATION. The final tool will be published when it is tested and proven in use.

Anycubic i3 Mega

title: Android Body for Google Home Mini

description.text:
(For more, follow us here and/or at @_insta_yaya_ on instagram!)

Give your Google Home Mini some personality! This Android-inspired body is a fun little addition to the Google home mini, designed to give it some personal touch in a shape we all know and love.

General notes
The main body design requires supports. The other parts do not.

You'll want to print one of each item, except arm rings (2) and connecting pins (4).

When printing the connecting pins, if you want a tight fit, experiment with scaling. I found that on my Prusa i3 MK2s, 102% was perfect for a tight snug fit.

I added some glue to get the two parts of each arm to fit tightly (choose your favorite glue). Also glued the neck-ring onto the main body.

The eyes and antennae are connected with tiny bits of hot-glue, which holds pretty well and comes right off if you're unhappy with its positioning (just don't smush it too hard into the fabric).

You'll notice the two holes in the main body designed for the arm connecting-pins stick out into the inner part of the body. Some light sanding may be required so they don't get in the way of the Google Home Mini. I edited the model to accommodate for it, but haven't re-printed since.

*Tip of the hat to lingen for his android design (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:525796) - even though this object was designed 100% from scratch in OpenSCAD, his design inspired some of the decisions I made for this.

author: skullndrones

description.text:
During my own FFF experiments I faced problems with fits. I couldn’t know how precisely the Makerbot that I use at my university does follow my 3D models. So I came up with the idea to create some kind of “meter” to find out what kind of clearances would be appropriate for “my” machine, material and CAM parameters (layer height, speed…)  
My solution for this problem is a block, which side shape is triangle and it has several holes, whose sizes increase in certain steps. The triangle shape allows to study that are there any differences between horizontal, vertical and 45-degree-from-normal shapes. The pins (or axles) have just one size, but they are also created in these orientations. These pins may also have chamfers or rounds. I named this system as “Renimeter” after my nickname ^^  
This meter with its pins tells you what kind of clearance (according to your CAD model) is suitable for tight or sliding fit with your machine, your materials and these CAM parameters without extra grinding or machining. Of course, if you measure the dimensions of holes and pins you may see how much gap there is between the cad model and the printed model. In my point of view this meter is suitable for other AM methods too.

The prime dimension of Renimeter basic is 10 mm and the clearance (or offset) increases 0.1 mm by each step. For instance, the 0.5 mm clearance of the hole’s dimension is 1 mm bigger than prime dimension (10 –> 11mm).  
Hole is basically considered as circle shape but my solution includes also square shapes, because in my opinion the current FFF machines create rectangle shapes more precisely than circle shapes. Why ? Because these machines operate in Cartesian coordinate system.  
According to my own experiments 0.5 mm clearance in horizontal direction is good value for sliding fit. It seems also that 45 degree pin has lover friction in these horizontal holes. (Machine: Makerbot Replicator, material: ABS, layer height: 0.2 mm, Fill: full solid).

The holes of this meter have same dimensions as basic one but they are optimized for FFF machines according to my point of view. There is no support needed in vertical or 45 degree shapes and horizontal shapes are good for Cartesian coordinated machine. It also seems like pins can be fitted in smaller holes than in basic meter.

In my way of thinking knowledge is meant to be spread. That’s why I added my creation to Internet for everyone. If you have questions about Renimeter, please contact me. These stl files are originally published on grabcad.com website.
Raspberry Pi Zero W + 2.5" HDD

My original mesh was a tire fire. This one is essentially a retopology of it. Same basic shape and whatnot, but it doesn't have any of the flipped normals, weird topology, etc. Also has a blend file with the wireframe so you can adjust stuff I might've screwed up on.

The "brackets" are that the box does not press itself apart because of the foam.

author: Sedgester

description.text:
This is a very WIP thing. It's supposed to be a heavy duty version of the Hypercube Evolution with linear rails for X and Y, a very solid milled aluminum gantry... also, it's a H-BOT design, rather than a Corexy! I know, right? H-bot suffers from racking when moving along the x-axis! But on lower accelerations it's so small it's hard to even notice it. It will be possible later on to turn it into a CoreXY with some additional parts (i.e: idler holders and x-carriage) I'm yet to design. In that case, it will be possible to use a much thinner plate for the X-gantry, like a 3.175mm instead of 6.35mm, since Corexy doesn't suffer racking around the Z axis.

The gantry plate is designed to fit inside a 300x200 or 300x300 hypercube evolution frame calculated with Scott's original spreadsheet.

The x-carriage can be set up either as a direct drive or as a bowden-style extruder by simply attaching the motor to the frame instead of on the top of the carriage. I like it direct-drive mode because it should give a much better performance with prints with a lot of small islands with a much smaller chance of clogging up the heatbreak. It also lets you use up to the last few centimeters of filament, rather than leaving 1m or so behind because the extruder gear can't grip it.

The build platform base is also a bit different from the original. I wanted something simpler and easier to align, so it's single-Z for now.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zY6mfKJ0MvU

title: Delta printer 64 mm Led lamp structure

description.text:
This is my first intent of make a nice led lamp holder to integrate in the delta printer structure. It was designed for the Anycubic Linear plus but it can be adapted without much effort for another delta printers.
Mounted with only one 3mm screw to the power source and printed without any support in about 90 minutes.

As a lamp you can get any round Led lamp, I used :
10W round Led lamp in aliexpress u$ 3.15 about 3€

ATTENTION: Do not connect a 12V Led lamp directly to your printer power !!!
Connect the Led lamp though a PWM potentiometer and do not push the thing to the limit. Diodes give a great source of light but they get really warm. So if you turn it too HIGH then it will raise temperature very fast and this plastic support will fall like a flower in winter.
I do not want to be responsible for any fire. So please take care of not burning the support :)

If you want to dim the led lamp then use one PWM potentiometer. Box is here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2814213

Note: This is a work in progress so a next version maybe coming soon.

author: rip1980

description.text: This is a design I made to support the #never again movement supporting gun control. from one angle it reads never from a different angle it read again.

These parts are designed to upgrade an existing direct driven 8mm leadscrew to a belt driven.
You can use as many leadscrews as you like.
The bearing mount has the same holes as a Nema 17 motor, so you can use your existing motor holders with this mod.

What you need:
-one motor holder ( it has mounting holes for 2020 extrusion)
-one bearing mount and a kfl008 bearing for each leadscrew

-a closed loop gt2 loop of proper lenght (I use a 600mm for my dual Z)
-Pulleys (one for the motor and one for each leadscrew)
-at least one m3 screw and idler as a belt tensioner (the motor holder has many holes to mount idlers)
-two m5x8mm screws and two m5 nuts to mount the KFL008 bearing.

Another option/design for the 40x40mm extrusion endcap.

The end hole on the aluminum extrusion must be tapped (5/16-18) before this cap will screw into place. Even If its already tapped, It wouldn't hurt to re-tap it to be sure you wont break the plug and have to reprint.

Screw it in gently, but backing it out a little if it starts feeling too tight and like it could break... then gently back in until its positioned adequately. This could take a couple repeats to get it sitting how you want it to.

I wanted a snug fit, but didn't want to snap or push anything... so this is the method I used. Ended up working alright with only 1 endcap casualty.

If you have any problems or need a different thread, just shoot me a message.

description.text:
Handy hangers

This project actually grew from some curtain rod hangers for wire shelving.
To warm up for that project, I created simple parametric hooks and hangers in Fusion 360.
This warm-up project took on a life of its own and has proven popular with my social media followers.

These are quick to print and super-handy.

Please comment with your experiences and we'll get STLs for other sizes posted.

Files included:

This post includes 2 styles in 4 shelf sizes.
The name of each STL includes the total height of the shelf it is designed for.
See the "Parametric!" section below for more information on how these are sized for different shelves.

There is also a public link in that section to the Fusion 360 project.

Notes:

Orientation and supports

All the hooks are printed on their side. I did not use a brim or raft, but if you have bed adhesion issues, you may want to add a brim.

  • The basic hangers are printed without supports.
  • The pegs require supports. Because the arm can be thin at certain sizes, you want to make sure the supports stick to the print bed. In my case, a little glue on the bed helped.

Materials

All of mine have been PLA so far.
I'l be printing some in PETG soon, but if you go that route, please comment and let me know if they are stiff enough.

Cleanup

The hangers should require no cleanup.

You'll need to knock the supports off the pegs.

Parametric!

This started with a parametric design for the shelf clip.
Most everything can be set parametrically, but you may need to adjust fillets and such.
Grab the Fusion 360 design and play with it!
If you have suggestions to fix problems, or if you have dimensions for other shelves, please post them in the comments so I can update this post.

I own two set of shelves:

  • Amazon Basics (350lb capacity)
  • Honey Do (200lb capacity)

I have printed and am using the hangers on those shelves.

In addition, I measured some shelves on my last trip to Home Depot:

  • HDX Black (350lb)
  • HDX Chrome (250lb)
    These have not been tested. If you make them, please comment with your results.
Sample shelf measurements

description.text:
This is an optical viewfinder to be used on a rangefinder camera such as Leicas, FEDs or Zorkies when using wide angle lenses such as Zeiss Biogon or the russian Jupiter-12 lenses. Unlike the built-in viewfinder of your FED or Leica,which is made for 50mm lenses, this viewfinder should give you the correct angle of view for 35 mm wide-angle lenses.
It may also be useful on a digital camera when you can't or dont want to use the screen.
The viewfinder will fit onto the standard hot- or coldshoe of most cameras.

You will need:

  • top and bottom of the viewfinder housing printed at a high resolution
  • a single use camera like this one: https://www.dm.de/paradies-einwegkamera-iso-400-27-bilder-p4010355787873.html
  • glue

How it's done:
1.Once the two parts of the housing are printed, cannibalize the single use camera to get the two lenses of the viewfinder.
(You may cover the lens and shoot/advance the film to also get a nice 400ASA film. another useful thing on these cameras are the flash electronics - but be very careful with the condensator!!!)

2.Once the lenses are extracted, they can be fitted into the housing. The curved sides of the lenses should face each other. Some filing/sanding may be required to fit them into the housing.

3.Clean everything and glue the two parts of the viewfinder.

Design notes:
i gutted the single use camera to get the lenses and carefully measured them and their distance. The viewfinder body was designed in Autodesc 123 with excessive use of polylines.

PS: sorry for the bad photos. they where made with a cellphone camera

author: bahafit

description.text: foot vase

PrintDry recently completed a kickstarter to begin production of a container to hold a single spool of filament and keep it dry. They work pretty well. The containers, unfortunately have no way of feeding filament out, so you have to remove the filament for printing, exposing it to moisture. This is especially problematic with polycarbonate and nylon filaments.

This thing is a filament spindle and feedthru to retrofit the PrintDry containers for filament feeding. This way you don't ever have to open up the container and expose the filament to moisture.

The spool holder uses a regular 608 skate bearing (8mmx22mmx7mm). Drill a 4mm hole in the center of the bottom of the PrintDry container. A 4x20mm bolt acts as the spindle. The hardware from the bottom is thus:
4mm bolt--printdry--printed bushing--bearing--printed spindle--washer--nut--nut
Tighten the double nuts against each other to prevent them from unscrewing themselves.

To assemble the filament guide, position, drill holes and mount with the m3 hardware that secures it. Then use a 4mm drill to drill thru the filament guides and PrintDry container. Fit a length of bowden tube in there for reduced friction. It should press fit.

The filament guides are coped to the diameter of the PrintDry contanier and are best printed with a brim and the horns facing upwards.

This utilizes the below parts,

  • x4: SSLV20/7 ZZ V-groove Bearings
  • x4: 1" L x 1/4" OD dowel
  • x1: Printed spool holder base

I got the inspiration for this from Periodic Table by hoffmanjon. I wanted to make my own version of it. This is basically a jigsaw of the periodic table with the symbols for each element on the pieces. It is in two parts, one with the first half of the periodic table and one with the second half. Note: The openSCAD file is both parts.

These are the current files for the 1 pound plastic fighting machine called "Plastique". I will post full parts lists and additional instructions, but for now I thought the parts would be of interest.

The only video I could find of this robot winning (it doesn't win much, it usually turtles) https://youtu.be/5kx_2t19lqg

Drive motors: N20 50:1 (or similar) x2 https://hobbyking.com/en_us/brushed-motor-15mm-6v-20000kv-w-50-1-ratio-gearbox.html?wrh_pdp=2
Tires: Lego small, wide tires. Photo included
Weapon motor: Hobby King "Donkey" brushless motor. Example: https://hobbyking.com/en_us/hobbyking-donkey-st3511-810kv-brushless-power-system-combo.html

I've used an assortment of brushed motor ESC for drive and brushless ESC's for the weapon. Any standard small combat robot ESC's will do, the smaller the better.

You'll need an assortment of 4-40 nuts and bolts.
At least 15cm of 6mm steel (or something) rod.
6mm ID shaft collars x2 (one for the top and one for the bottom)
Small Reciever, bot requires 3 channels (2x for drive 1x for weapon)
One light duty spring, approx 1" diameter.
One 1" foam (or other) tire for the weapon drive.

The shell does draw a lot of current spinning up, so a larger battery is better. No less than 250mah for 3 minute battle.

remixed_from.author: hashtagdavi
remixed_from.title: OctoPi Rig (Raspberry Pi 3 & Logitech C170 Webcam)

description.text:
This Thing listing is a conversion of my original OctoPi Rig, though it has been modified exclusively to work with the Printrbot Simple Metal!

This rig is designed to use the Raspberry Pi 3 and a Logitech C170 webcam. You will need these in order to build this OctoPi Rig, along with a MicroSD card of at least 4GB, and can freely download the software image you will need to use from the Octoprint website. I highly recommend watching the video tutorial on their site while following the installation instructions provided there as well.

The rig includes a case designed for the Raspberry Pi 3, a GoPro style mount for the Logitech webcam, and GoPro style corner mounts for the Printrbot Simple Metal's print bed. There are 2 versions of the corner mount: One is made to hold the camera mount so it faces the print bed at a 45 degree angle relative to the print bed, while the second version will hold the camera mount at a 30 degree angle relative to the print bed.

You must decide on which version of the camera mount to use based on the size of your printer's print bed size. Stock beds are usually more square shaped which entails using the 45 degree camera mount to position the Logitech c170 Webcam at the right angle to capture the whole print bed in frame. Upgrade print bed kits, like a heated bed upgrade kit for example, feature a print bed with a more rectangular shape to their design. For these print beds, the 30 degree camera mount will be more adequate, as the angle for the Logitech Webcam is sharper, allowing it to capture the extended print bed within frame!

Happy Printing & Enjoy :-)

title: Anet A8 Y-Belt Clip (6mm spacing w/ 1.38mm thick belt)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I designed this thing from scratch with freecad using full and proper gt2 belt geometry. Yes, here we have a true 3 radius tooth design, not some slapped together polygon approximation. You'll feel the luxury the first time you insert a belt, LOL.

I did some test print and tweak iterations to get the thickness (in abs) just right for a snug fit on the 1.38mm thick GT2 belts I use (the drawing is tuned at 1.78mm to account for tolerances of my printer... any smaller and the fit feels too tight). I designed the top counter-bores a tad deeper (so the shells for the screw head and belt are touching). This means you have to loosen those 2 bolts before you insert a belt (it won't fit if they are pretightened). Then after the belt ends are inserted, tightening the top bolts will clamp down on the belt.

The 20x12mm bolt pattern fits my newer Anet A8 y-carriage (c.a. Jan 2018). Beware depending on how you initially assembled your y carriage, this may not fit without some reassembly work... the attached file is for 6mm carriage spacing (6.5mm actually, since I'm ocd and that fit my a8 better). If you haven't heard of this before, the picture shows my carriage where the 'cross bar' is mounted under the bearing bars (this is "6mm spacing"). If your crossbar is top mounted, this won't fit.

Again, the attached version is for common 1.38mm thick reprap fg reinforced belts; if folks ask I can upload versions for other gt2 belt thicknesses. Please don't ask because I won't upload a version with 10mm carriage spacing. The 6mm spacing carriage setup is IMHO preferable due to the smaller offset of forces (= less deformation from torque). Uploading a 10mm version serves to perpetuate this common error.

a8

description.text:
NEED SOME SMALL EXTENSION OF THE END STOP PINS DIRECTION!

Can mount 2 E3d v6 heads with no need to modify the coldend.
Doest eat up alot of print space and has proper cooling for E3d's and printed parts.
cable management with ziptie on the clamps.

Can be printed without any support generation from any slicer!

*part cooling not yet tested. but think it this should suffice, incase the 50x15 radial fan doesn't have enough airflow/pressure the just plug up some holes with some filament since the holes are 2mm in diameter.

On a side note the main part of the frame should be 50mm wide... mine was always 0.5mm off when printing so i scaled it to 101% in the XY plane. In case the bearings are too lose in the frame then wrap them with some tape untill they fit snugly without wobble, and dont over tighten the 4 scews or it will deform the bearings a bit and lockup the asembly.

The distance between the nozzle's should be 32mm, any deviation possible due mounting in a 3d printed part etc and obv reasons.

BOM:
4x 45mm m3 screws
5x 12+mm m3 screws
9x m3 nut (or 5 normal and 4 self locking for on the bottom side)
2x 50x15 radial fan
4x times LM8UU or igus dryline

Future additions/modificatons:
BL touch sensor mount. (dont have one yet but am considering it)
Actual clamp method for the radial fans instead of pressfit/glue.

Also place parts in a logical direction. (halfs of where the bearings go the open part should be up and the clamps on their back side to prevent sagging)

I mit hus fra 1962 er jeg ved at udskifte de originale kontakter, med FUGA kontakter. De gamle kontakter er 70mm brede. Når jeg bruger Softline 68 rammer, ser det grimt ud, da der er et mellemrum i mellem tapetet og kontakten.

Jeg har derfor lavet min egen ramme, som jeg kalder Super Softline 71. Den udmærker sig ved at:

  • 71mm bred, så det ser pænt ud når man udskifter en kontakt.
  • Afrundet på alle kanter.
  • Har et 3x1 modul, der passe i hvor en gammel 1 + 1½ sad.
  • 1½ modul kan bruges omvendt.
    Bemærk at nogle filer findes både som system 50 og 68. System 50 er det nuværene system, de fleste kende til. System 68 er til gamle huse, hvor kontakterne er omkring 68 mm brede.

Notes:

Printing this at the default size requires bridging a 2.25 mm gap - at the top of the grooves cut into the lid. Before you print, you should examine the layers your slicer produces. Rotate the model until the first bridged layer is perpendicular to the gap.

From this image, I re-created the lid design on a grid. Turning it into a box from the coordinates was straightforward.

The mechanism by which the lid attaches isn't obvious from the image. The design I have come up with is a compromise to make it easy to print without support.

The STL files here leave a 0.5mm clearance between the tongue and groove. If you scale down the STL files, the clearance will also be reduced, which may prevent the lid from fitting well.

A better way to re-size the box is to download the OpenSCAD file and re-generate the STL. Change the "scaling" variable to make the box bigger or smaller. This will resize the model while maintaining the same clearance.

If you need more clearance, increasing the "tol" variable.

This is a 3 switch control box that incorporates inexpensive single pole single throw micro (3.5mm by 7mm) momentary switches. This part is used for providing left, right, and select input for a stepper motor controlled by an Arduino or Node MCU. You can see how to assemble the box in the files. Not shown is the wiring. The hole in the box is designed to take Ethernet cable (Cat 5, etc) which brings in 4 twisted pairs of 24 AWG wire. You solder 3 of the pairs to the switches (there are small metal tabs on either side that are connected when the switch button is pressed). You'll have a spare pair of wires when done.

I ordered the switches from here: https://www.amazon.com/Uxcell-Momentary-Button-Tactile-Switch/dp/B00E6QJRT4 but they are available elsewhere (http://www.uxcell.com/pcs-7mm-35mm-spst-pins-momentary-push-button-smd-smt-tactile-tact-switch-p-412051.html).

description.text:
This is a track connector for the Toys'r'Us store-brand of car tracks, marketed as Fast Lane in Canada (and maybe elsewhere). The track packs don't come with enough connectors to set them up in a different configuration from the one on the box, so I made a few of these for my son. It should let you connect an unlimited number of tracks end-to-end.

You can fit 5x of these on the print bed of a small printer like the Monoprice Select Mini. They take about half an hour each to print at standard settings. Something strong & flexible like PETG is probably best, since these things will take a lot of abuse from an active kid.

I made this in OpenSCAD, and included the source file to allow adjustments. The provided STL file works very well for me, but you may want to downsize the triangular protrusions a bit. I made the locking connectors a bit larger than the original to form a more secure connection. If the tolerances on your tracks are different, then reducing the triangle size and increasing the separation by a mm or two might give you more wiggle room.

I have no affiliation with Toys'r'Us or the Fast Lane brand of toys.

description.text:
This tool I designed is able to cut styrofoam and soft wood (balsa, spruce/pine).
Working part length is ~38cm. You can apply the vertical scaling and modify length of the regular middle part if you need to get other length of the tool (this part could be not used at all, or installed twice).
Power supply is connected to washers on M8 threaded rods, which is isolated from the 12mm aluminium tube by capton tape. Nichrome string is attached to washers, wich is tightened between nuts on the rods. Length of the string between washers should be ~1cm shorter then dimension between rods (for pre-tension).
I use 0.3mm nichrome string at 12V, but you can experimentally choose other combination for your applications.
For cutting wood, use thicker string and/or higher voltage, than for styrofoam. If temperature is not high enough, move instrument back and forth like when sawing. I found it better for cutting thin wood parts with hot wire rather then with the jig saw or dremel tool because this does not provide any noise and dust (convinient for not disturbing anyone, and proceed with modelling even at night).

Please take precautions when handling electricity. Be sure to test the circuit before applying the working voltage. Ensure twice, that you eliminated the possibility of electrical contact between the rods and aluminium tube (especially after tensioning the string).

UPD: added separate .stl for every part without brim and .stp without brim.
But I recommend to print the handle with brim anyway.

P.S. I am still working on my english, please let me know if something is wrong.

Printer:

Modified UP!Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25x0.6 mm

Infill:

20-50%

Notes:

The model is already scaled to 1.003 (100.3%) for slightly better assemblability and to compensate ABS shrinking. If it does not needed in your case, apply the scaling to 0.997 (99.7%).

• 43cm of 12mm square aluminium tube
  • 2x 16cm M8 threaded rod
  • M8: 10 nuts and 6 washers
  • button: installation size 13x18mm, external frame size 15x21mm
  • appropriate wires
  • capton tape or similiar thin isolation material
  • 40-45cm of 0.2-0.4mm nichrome or steel string, depending on voltage you prefer to use (mine is working good with 0.3mm nichrome at 12V)

Disclaimer: Use at your own risk. This is a freebie from the internet. No warranty. 3D printed lens adapters are very imperfect. Do not trust this to hold your expensive vintage Leica lens. Don't trust it to hold your grandfather's Leica lens. It may look precise but there is a lot of guesswork and just eyeballing it that went into the construction of this.

The all metal adapters are inexpensive and more accurate. This is to try out a lens in a carpeted area while that adapter is in the mail. This is to play with cheap Russian lenses that are L39 mount.

Doesn't focus at infinity? It might not quite do it for you. Try closing the lens up to ƒ/8 - that's pretty good for landscape.

title: Cheap DIY 3KU Removable Flexible Print Bed mod

description.text:
Prusa MK3 inspired removable flexible build plate for 3ku Delta v1

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yxGM_-663uE

This is one of the best upgrades Ive ever done to this printer. Removing prints can be such a pain in the butt. On my Taz6, Ive actually cut my self removing prints that stuck to the PEI sheet to well. Even on the 3ku it's hard to remove stuck prints because the towers get in the way of your arms and removal tools. Not to mention the removal tools can even damage your print bed surface and the model being printed.

No more. Prints come off print bed with ease, and without tool marks. And no cut hands.

This is a DIY project so some trade off's where made. Namely the type of metal sheet used. Prusa is using spring steel. The buildtak flexplate system is also using spring steel, because it remembers its shape after flexing alot better then most metals. But I couldn't source it locally in larger sizes. Everything was in 6in wide x 12in or 24in. And it would have been more expensive. So the stuff home depots sells is what was recommended.

The hardest part of this whole thing is cutting the metal sheet. I gave my work buddy the template linked below. He clamped it between two pieces of wood, before cutting it. That way it wouldn't curl up. He used a jig saw to cut the sheet. The screw holes came out rough and I needed to file them more open. Also I had to file the edges of metal all around the circumference of plate. Make sure the screw cut off line up with screws. More filing may have to be done to enlarge the cutouts. You want the screw cutouts to be just as big as they need to be, not bigger. File down any remaining rough edges. The screw cutouts actually help the magnets from stopping any lateral movement of the bed.

After you have a fitting sheet plate, your golden. Cut the silicone double sided tape into the shapes of magnets. Place the magnets with silicone tape evenly spaced out around the heat pad.

One touch leveling with nozzle as probe still works because the plate is also metal just like the aluminum plate. So redo your auto calibration and bed leveling just like previously. Then apply your choice of surface and print. The magnets are very strong anyway, just an added security.
Ended up using 7 magnets. I dont know what effect adding a magnet to the center of heat pad will have, so I just placed magnets around the heat pad. I didn't have to double the magnets for more pulling force, however I did add more magnets then shown in pic because with just 4 magnets, there were places the plate wasnt flush with heat bed. I still have to test if repeated plate removals will effect bed leveling. I wonder if over time plate will become unlevel from removals and repeated bending, it not being spring steel after all. I'll report back.

Credit to Improper Engineering for a DIY version of Prusa's MK3 bed
https://youtu.be/-HI0PLQ3ThU

Materials:
Build Surface
Blue tape, BuildTak, Lokbuild, PEI

author: MovieMaker

description.text:
Here is a fun dispenser for your collection of washi tape!

In addition to prints of both sides, you will need:
--3 mini hacksaw blades (6" long)
--3 spring-loaded toilet paper roll holders
--3 pieces of 3/8" dowel cut to 5 and 3/4" long
--6 screws, size 6, 3/4" long
--screwdriver
--drill with tiny-sized bit for drilling pilot holes

To assemble:

  1. Paint your dowels if desired.
  2. Pre-drill pilot holes into the ends of the dowels to prevent splitting.
  3. Using screws, firmly attach all 3 dowels to one 3D printed side.
  4. Using screws, loosely attach the second 3D printed side to 2 or 3 of the dowels.
  5. Hook the pins on the ends of the 3 hacksaw blades through the slots on the 3D printed sides.
  6. Tighten the screws on the second 3D printed side to hold the hacksaw blades in place. (This will require some finagling. The blades need to be held firm and taunt. Trim your dowels slightly shorter if the 3D printed sides are forced to bend too much.)
  7. Slide your rolls of washi tape onto the toilet paper roll holders and install them in the large holes.
  8. Enjoy the convenience of easy access to your washi tape!

title: 1/10 scale AGM-65 Maverick missile for the Freewing A-10
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
1/10 scale AGM-65 Maverick missile for the Freewing A-10 Thunderbolt II. My goal was to make a stand-off scale version of the missile in case you want to change the load out of your a-10 or if the original missile was lost or damaged. The missile has a pocket for using the mounting plate (Thing Number 2725747) designed by ShadowVFX.

I sized the parts to fit into a 150 mm cube size printer. I changed the Infill density from 15% to 3% to make it lighter. My printer just used a single hourglass shaped fill pattern. The final painted weight was 49 grams. Make sure that you enable support when printing the first stage part as fins do not touch the build plate. All the other parts do not require any additional support.

You only need to print the lens part if you are going to use a clear vacuum formed nose cap. The lens part will also fit on the front of the original foam missile if you use a clear nose cap. The printed nose cap can be used as a vacuum form plug to pull a clear nose cap

title: GEPRC Sparrow Motor and Frame bumper

description.text:
Protection pour châssis et moteur du GEPRC Sparrow

Protection designer pour une taille moteur 1407, convient parfaitement aux autres moteurs plus petits. Les hauteurs de SoftMount sont de 0.6 mm et 1.2 mm.

La distance entre la protection et le moteur est suffisante pour permettre une bonne rotation et un bon refroidissement tout en assurant la protection du moteur et du châssis en cas de choc.

Possibilité d'imprimer sans les supports du trancheur et ainsi avoir de meilleurs finissions, un temps d'impression réduit et moins de matière utilisée. Pour cela :

1 - Imprimer la pièce support en PLA ou autres,
2 - Démarrer l'impression avec le TPU jusqu’à la hauteur de 4 mm,
3 - Insérer la pièce support dans l'emplacement,
4 - Continuer et finir l'impression,
5 - Avec un objet fin décoller la pièce support du TPU et tirer la en arrière

Pour une meilleur accroche du TPU sur la pièce support, la mettre coté lisse vers le haut et rajouter une fine couche de laque dessus

_____

GEPRC Sparrow Chassis and Engine Protection

Designer protection for a 1407 engine size, ideal for other smaller engines. The heights of SoftMount are 0.6 mm and 1.2 mm.

The distance between the protection and the motor is sufficient to allow a good rotation and a good cooling while ensuring the protection of the engine and the chassis in case of shock.

Ability to print without the slicer supports and thus have better finishes, reduced printing time and less material used. For it :

1 - Print the support part in PLA or others,
2 - Start printing with the TPU up to the height of 4 mm,
3 - Insert the support piece in the slot,
4 - Continue and finish printing,
5 - With a thin object take off the support piece of the TPU and pull it back

For a better grip of the TPU on the support piece, put it smooth side up and add a thin layer of lacquer on

title: Desk Fan Using 120mm x 120mm x 38mm 12V Fan

description.text:
First off, let me please ask that if you like these designs and find them useful please do like, follow and share my content. And if you have any ideas or concepts to modify the content I would love to hear!

I wanted a powerful and affordable desktop fan that I could run off of 12v in my office and also in my camper van when travelling. I chose a 120mm x 120mm x 38mm 12v DC fan from Sunon to design the shroud around. Any 120mm computer/CPU/server fan within those size constraints will fit this design as well.

This is the fan I designed it for: http://au.element14.com/sunon/eec0381b1-0000-a99/fan-standard-120mm-12vdc/dp/1924843?mckv=sESiX4QFR_dc%7Cpcrid%7C59148083448%7Cpkw%7C%7Cpmt%7C%7Cslid%7C%7Cproduct%7C1924843%7C&gross_price=true&CATCI=pla-401503001734&CAAGID=12550800888&CMP=KNC-GOO-SHOPPING-1924843&CAGPSPN=pla&gclid=CjwKCAiArOnUBRBJEiwAX0rG_aa0wg-5h_UpC6d2YvQ9MACcRZtydnVBaMXSUIBey_pCmE9QDPTuRxoCX34QAvD_BwE&CAWELAID=120185580000262561

The PWM motor controller I am using is a 12v Board with a potentiometer for speed control and PCB mounting dimensions 50mm x 31mm between centre of mounting holes. This is it here http://www.dx.com/p/pwm-dc-converter-motor-speed-controller-switch-green-12v-36v-10a-226934#.WptOTyNL2CQ

I use a AC (240V) to DC (12V) power supply with a 2.1mm two-contact jack for power. A location for the potentiometer and 2.1mm DC jack to be hard-mounted to the case has been given.

I have left this as a work in progress design as I wish to finish the detailing and aesthetics. As well as an auto-swing/controlled mechanism on the directional fins. I'm thinking ATTINY85 and a servo to keep costs down. At this point the fins are to be held in place with M3 socket head cap screws.

Be sure to let me know what you think. I would love to hear!

Kind regards,

James A.

Mankati Fullscale XT Plus

This is a simple mount for the 8mm proximity sensor. It used the existing 3mm mounting holes on the side of the original fan shroud.

You can enable the auto bed level feature with the original Sanduino board, however, you will need to trim the code a bit. I commented out some unnecessary LCD features that I didn't need. I removed all of the features under "Motion", leaving only the Z offset option. My final code uses 96% of the storage memory.

I hope this helps some one.

Take care,

title: Roman Numeral Trainer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A simple game to learn or improve your understanding of the Roman numeral system.

Printer:

Sculpto+

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes:

How many coins should I print?
As many as you want! I would suggest printing at least 3 of each value.

The coins are quite large, can I print them smaller?
Absolutely, the full size coins are probably best for the individual value and the sort the numbers excercises. I have printed coins in 60% size successfully (STLs for this are in the files section), they will likely print even smaller but I wouldn't recommend that.

description.header: What is the Roman Numeral System?
description.text:
The numeric system represented by Roman numerals originated in ancient Rome and remained the usual way of writing numbers throughout Europe well into the Late Middle Ages. Numbers in this system are represented by combinations of letters from the Latin alphabet. Roman numerals, as used today, are based on seven symbols: I=1, V=5, X=10, L=50, C=100, D=500, M=1000
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roman_numerals

The Roman numerals are added or subtracted based on their position in the written number. A smaller number before a larger number means the smaller number is subtracted from the larger. A larger number before a smaller number means the smaller number is added to the larger number.

It can sound quite complicated when explained, but 3 simple bulletpoints should be enough:

  • Small before large, subtract the small number from the larger number.
  • Large before small, add the two.
  • Never put more than one smaller number before a larger number.
Examples

I = 1
II = 2
III = 3 (NEVER IIV!)
IV = 4
VI = 6
CIV = 104
MMXVIII = 2018

Individual values

If you've never worked with Roman numerals before, the first thing you should master is the individual values. Identifying the individual values is the basis for everything invovling Roman numerals.

Put the coins in a bag or put them, value side down, on a table. Draw a coin and identify the value. Keep going until you master the values.

Sort the numbers

A variation on the individual values excercise, take one coin of each value and sort the coins from small to large. You will need to identify the values before you can sort them correctly.

Growing number

The idea of this excercise is to improve your understanding of the structure of the Roman numeral system.

Put all the coins in a bag or on the table with the value facing down. Draw a coin and identify the value (as in the individual value excercise). Draw another coin and identify the combined value of the two. Keep going as long as you want or until you can no longer figure the number out. Use a tool like http://www.onlineconversion.com/roman_numerals_advanced.htm to validate your number.

Each coin drawn should be added to the end of the number, unless that would create an invalid number. If the coin cannot be added to the end of the number, add it to the start and continue. If the the coin cannot be added to either start or end of the number string, re-arrange your coins to make a valid number and continue. The goal is to become familiar with the structure of a valid Roman numeral.

As an example, consider these four draws:

  1. I = 1
  2. V, IV = 4
  3. C, IVC is invalid, move the C to the front to get CIV = 104.
  4. I, both CIVI and ICIV are invalid numbers and you cannot continue. Re-arrange your coins to make a valid a number. A valid number could be CVII = 107.
Got an idea for another excercise?

If you have ideas for other excercises, feel free to share them in the comments!

title: Linear Ball Bearing Stepper Side v2

description.text:
28BYJ-48 Mechanical Actuator #5

I thought it would be cool to see what kind of Mechanical Actuators we could make using the 28BYJ-48 stepper motor and mostly 3D printed parts. The 28BYJ-48 is the motor that comes with most Arduino kits. It's a 5v dc motor with a max rpm of 15 and is capable of around 4 oz force/in of torque. You can get these motors with the driver for around $2 each.

Linear Ball Bearing Stepper Slide

This is a remix of the first Liner Bearing Stepper Slide I made. The bearing carriage on the first slide is slit down the center of the bearing groove but on this version I thought that I would design the bearing more similar to an actual linear bearing so it has a solid carriage and end caps for the bearing return. Since the print orientation is different on this version I was able to utilize Gothic bearing grooves typical to the type on an actual linear bearing instead of a “V” groove like I used on the first version.

I was hoping for a little smother transition of the balls to reduce the noise and vibration but I think both designs preform very similar. The first design is actually a little easier to assemble.

=====================================================================

This is a linear bearing slide driven by a 28BYJ-48 stepper motor. The linear bearing utilizes standard .177 (4.5mm) caliber steel BB’s and has adjustment screws for setting the preload. The trapezoidal drive screw utilizes an integral ball bearing also made with BB’s to handle the thrust loads of the slide.

I included two different lead screws; a twin lead screw with a 1/2” pitch and a quadruple lead screw with a 1” pitch. Given the max rpm of the stepper motor is 15 rpm the twin lead screw will result in the carriage traveling at 7-1/2 in per/min and the quadruple lead screw will travel at 15 in per/min.

The linear bearing actually works very well and the BB’s recirculate just as they are supposed to! There is some noise and vibration as the BB’s are not caged and I think they meet a little resistance as they recirculate back into the bearing. On the next version I’m going to split the housing like an actual linear bearing to see if it improves on the vibrations.

This slide will actually move over 25 lbs with the twin lead screw! If you have seen the previous Dovetail Stepper Slide it could move around 7lbs so this version has a 4x’s the load capacity do to its reduced friction. However the load is not as stable as it is on the dovetail slide. I believe the dovetail slide can handle more load it’s just the stepper motor is not strong enough to push it.

The mounting holes on the base, carriage, and the endplate all match up so multiple slide assemblies can be bolted together to make a two or three axis cartesian system.

=====================================================================

Required Components

  • M3 Nut (14x)
  • M3 SHCS x 10mm lg. (12x)
  • M3 SHCS x 20mm lg. (2x)
  • .177 BB’s (8x) for Thrust Bearing
  • .177 BB’s (8x) for Linear Bearing
  • 28BYJ-48 Stepper Motor

Assembly

To start assembly the first thing you need to do is install the two M3 x 20mm screws and nuts into the carriage for the preload adjustment. Don’t tighten the screws up at this point. Then use the M3 x 10mm screws to install one endcap and slide the bearing onto the rail. Next fill the bearing up with BB’s, it should take 34. Next put the remaining 6 BB’s in the other end cap. Here is the hard part, you have to move the carriage to the end of the rail and carefully tip the end cap with the 6 BB’s onto the carriage without dropping any of them. It may take one or two tries. Once the bearing is packed with BB's adjust the screws to get the desired preload. Once you have the linear bearing properly set you can build the thrust bearing flange.

Note: Using grease on the thrust bearing, drive screw, and nut is going to improve the load capacity and the lifecycle greatly as well as reduce noise and vibration. I would not put any lube on the ball bearings, it could cause issues with the balls recycling. If you are having trouble with the BB’s recycling you can also try taking out one of the BB’s on each side.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hzth1Ne-0JE
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6R109NuJiwY

title: Replacement jacks for a 1970 Goble harpsichord

description.text: These things replace the jacks in Goble harpsichords (1970 model). Being plastic, and made over 40 years ago, they may have become brittle or broken, and are otherwise irreplaceable these days. Mine had!

First check your harpsichord is a Robert Goble made around 1970. Otherwise they will not fit. Next acquire some tongues, plectra and adjustment screws from Hubbard Harpsichords http://www.hubharp.com/ and some felt for the dampers. Then print 61 of each jack and 183 damper clips. (75%, no raft nor support needed). Cut felt and glue it to the base of the dampers. Assemble each jack with a damper, a tongue, screws, and a plectrum. Then restore your harpsichord and play Bach!

title: Throttle body with position sensor to suit Subaru EJ20 motor

description.text:
This is a working throttle body to suit Eric's EJ20 motor. While building the motor, I was inspired by Skip20 https://www.thingiverse.com/make:428156 and the throttle body he added to the intake manifold. I thought it would be cool to taken this idea a step further and added a throttle position sensor to control the speed of the motor.

Throttle body can be seen working here https://youtu.be/V2c5cIhjmyU

Note...The file "Assembly.stl" is only for viewing in Thingiverse and not intended for printing.

The position sensor is a RK097 series miniature potentiometer and directly replaces the pot on your pwm motor controller. These pots are commonly available from most electronic component retailer including:

  • eBay https://www.ebay.com/sch/i.html?_from=R40&_trksid=p2380057.m570.l1313.TR0.TRC0.H0.XRK097.TRS0&_nkw=RK097&_sacat=0
  • RS Comp https://uk.rs-online.com/web/p/potentiometers/7293464/
  • Farnell http://au.element14.com/alps/rk09711110k/potentiometer-10k/dp/1191710?ost=RK097&ddkey=http%3Aen-AU%2FElement14_Australia%2Fsearch
  • Jaycar

When choosing a pot, note that the butterfly only rotates through 90 degree's. So you'll need to choose a pot with a value that suitable within 90 degrees.
Attach the throttle body by inserting M3 brass knurled nuts into the existing holes in the intake manifold.

author: Swanny

description.text:
So to preface this, This design is heavily inspired by the brain3d case, insomuch as I looked at it, liked it and took cues from its design when designing this. I really like the brain3d mount, it looks super easily printable, just a bit expensive when I have a printer and tpu...and that was my goal when creating this, cheap and printable, a lot of mounts on here look great but need so much support my printer was having a lot of trouble printing them.

So I started from scratch with (https://grabcad.com/library/gopro-hero4-session-2) <-this model, so props to that guy or gal, great model and saved me a ton of time. I printed it and it fits really well, gopro is snug, and there is room for a strap(if you are paranoid like me, it fits perfectly on the screw holes, which you will need longer screws btw (I mean duh?). The door is accessible, and it is well protected, I cant comment how well it will hold up in a crash but...should be good. Find your gopro and print another if it manages to get ripped off. Print in tpu, I printed mine in some cheap 25 dollar per kilo stuff off of amazon and it worked out really well...

Im releasing a step file so that people may modify it for angle or other purposes (it always annoys me how no one does this, honestly this took me about an hour to design, its really not worth it to hold onto the files so tightly...). I am releasing it under attribution and share alike, if you modify it and make it better, its always cool to help out other people, but I dont really care that much...If you modify it I always like a shout out...but once again not really that big of a deal...if you think its worth it to print it and try to make some money...go for it...but its probably not that good...

title: space filling sphenoid hendecahedrons - crystal rods

description.text:
The sphenoid hendecahedron is a space filling polyhedron. It is special in its low symmetry and creates visually pleasing patterns when rod like sub assemblies are formed. Considerable credits go to Guy Inchbald who published geometric data and description of these structures here
http://www.steelpillow.com/polyhedra/five_sf/five.htm 2011 William Adams aka WilliamAAdams
published a printable version of the more symmetric
bisymmetric hendecahedron spacefiller
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12800

description.text:
UPDATE: Added model, "Aquarium_Hideou_Rock_Large Supports.stl, with updated supports. These seem to print better. This should also severely reduce the amount of support material need to print the object.

I needed a hiding spot for a male Molly in my classroom fish tank to hide due to an aggressive "alpha" male molly. So I remixed "Rock 5 - Solid" from the Rock Formations design.

I hollowed it with meshmixer, tweaked it with Tinkercad, reduced the tri count and added supports, to reduce printing time. I am currently printing my test print and it is set to take 21 hrs according to Cura. It is rather large and was designed to fit the Dremel 3d40 build plate. In order to slice for the 3d40 you must resize to 98%. I was a tad off on my calculation when tweaking the model and adding the entrance and top hole for the fish to swim through.

I hope it works out well for you! It's my first upload on Thingiverse.

Oh and I left a tab all the way around the inside bottom of the model to cover with gravel and hold down in the aquarium better.

Once the parts are printed clean up the tabs with a file and superglue the edges.

I got sick of all the different lightsaber designs cutting corners on the Graflex clip. Either the whole thing is a single piece and rigid, or it uses a hard to print pin. Most of the designs also do not include the text and lines found on the original part.

I decided to try and make a fully working Graflex clip that is also in separate pieces to allow for sanding, filling, and then covering with standard aluminum duct tape to give a more accurate look to the piece.

One change to the design was to do only three lines instead of four and to make the text more bold. This was done so that the resolution could be seen on most printers and when covering with the tape, you can still get rub the piece hard enough for the design to show through.

There are two versions of the main clip:

  • One is a stock Graflex clip
  • The second has the two holes cut out for the side buttons found on Obi-Wan's lightsaber in ANH.

This is a still a work in progress but it is getting close. If you download and print, please share any thoughts of changes you wish to see.
A M3 nut and a short piece of M3 threaded rod will be needed to complete the tightening clasp.

remixed_from.title: Parametric pulley - lots of tooth profiles

description.text:
As I'm upgrading my ORAC lathe, one function I want to play around with is precision spindle control. This timing pulley fits on the spindle, inside the headstock. It connects to the stepper pulley via a 320-2GT timing belt. The stepper is mounted inside the headstock with my ORAC Spindle Stepper Mount.

This pulley can also hold a couple tiny magnets and along with my ORAC Hall Effect Sensor Mount set you up for a cheap digital tach.

As I'm upgrading my ORAC lathe, one function I want to play around with is precision spindle control. This mount holds a NEMA 23 stepper inside the headstock. The stepper is connected to the spindle via my ORAC Spindle Pulley, ORAC Spindle Stepper Pulley, and a 320-2GT timing belt.

The bolt posts are designed to be printed as plated without supports.

title: LNS Technologies 150A Injection Molding Machine Material Funnel

description.text:
This is a funnel for injection molding pellets that fits an LNS Technologies 150A desktop injection molding machine.

I made it to speed up the process of dropping pellets into the barrel of the machine. It has a little flap that is held shut with tension from a rubber band (I used a hair band) and you press it to drop pellets into the barrel.

Any questions ask in the comments.

I printed it from PLA on a Creality CR-10S

Once it is all printed place the flap in the bottom part of the funnel shoot and super glue the top part on top of it to hold it in place. The rest is held in with the two pins and the funnel screws in to the top of the shoot. You can use it with just the funnel or the cylinder to hold more material in. You don't need to glue the cylinder.
