print_settings.Notes:: My printer model is actually a Da Vinci Pro 3 in 1 but that isn't on the list and you have to pick something on the list.

description.text:
The print pictured was removed from the printer and filled with water. It was printed using ABS with a layer height of .3 mm and 25% infill.

I had trouble with the thin walls on the original so I added 4 mm walls to the sides and a 5 mm base. The side walls are a little taller than the original but, this makes for a small rim around the top edge to prevent water spillage whilst filling!

While the added amount of thickness might have been overkill, it prints perfectly and doesn't leak - unless you jostle it around a whole bunch while taking it out to show everyone in the neighborhood. In which case, a spray can of plasti dip comes in real handy.

Thanks to the original designer! Your design is perfect in every way, my printer just has special needs. I noticed someone else had similar troubles and thought that this edit might prove helpful to others.

This is my very first remix - I've made models but have never tried to add to, or rework a finished model. I was worried about how the old and new layers would interact and imagined the added layers just falling off when it was pulled from the print bed.

Fortunately, that didn't happen!

The base took a couple of attempts because it kept wrinkling. I wanted to maintain the integrity of that beautiful little Romanesque style drain at the bottom so, the original base is still inside of the added base.

I focused on adding function rather than aesthetics and there are a couple of exterior corners that might be a trigger for someone with OCD. Next time I upload, I will make sure the symmetry is as tight as the functionality.

Everything was done in XYZmaker and it printed on an XYZ printer. There doesn't seem to be any slicing or layering issues through multiple runs.

Hope it prints well for everyone!

Thoughts and suggestions are always appreciated!

Have a great day! :)

I use my Topping Nx4 as my portable dac/amp and also as my desktop dac/amp so i decided to design something to use as a dock when im not on the go. I included cut outs for the knob, switches, inputs and both usb slots in the back.

The desktop holder was designed to fit the NX4 with the velcro stickies that were included (check pictures). I decide to use double sided tape on the bottom of the dock to make it a permanent feature on my desk.

Let me know if you guys want any adjustments done to the design for version 2. Thank you!

author: ToastyFishsticks

description.text:
Rear windscreen wiper cover for Porsche Cayenne 955 2003.
After the windscreen wiper cover got knocked off some how I purchased one from Porsche spare parts.
I had to buy both the cover and the rear window handle/lock switch too, NZ$100 ish
In another country I could get one on Ebay for $10
I broke the little plastic catch inside trying to put it on.
Had to buy a second one. . Got a panel beater to put it on the car.
2 years later that too fell off and I ran over it on the driveway.
So I thought i would design one. I had the new unused base to keep trying the fit.
I made about 10 that were wrong. But thats whats so good about having a 3d printer for prototyping. Kind of a replacement for planning.
First one I have made is in PLA and I will make another in ABS as black can get pretty hot and it will fail.
Happy to share.

description.text:
Updates:
2018-03-11 - added versions for 20x4x3 mm magnets
2018-03-10 - added an offset paddle and angled button case (user request).
2018-03-08 - replaced all STLs. Now, you can add magnets (optional).

WRC Style Paddle Shift.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Md1_aOe4Amg

For Thrustmaster T500, use button_case_t500.stl

button_case_generic.stl is the generic base that uses 4 x M5 bolts/screws to secure to your own mount.

Items required:
2 x 12mm Momentary Push Button Round Switch
1 x M6 x 35mm screw
1 x M6 lock nut or lock
some wire
USB controller (optional). I wire mine up to the steering wheel's existing connections.
Magnets (optional) - 4 x 6.35 x 6.35 x 2.5 mm Neodymium magnets. Example: https://aussiemagnets.com.au/product/--6.35-x---6.35-x---2.5mm-Block-%28Rare-Earth%29.html
The magnets are tight fitting, for me anyway. I press it against the table to push them in. If they are loose, then best to apply some glue.

For button_case_t500.stl:
3 x replacements screws, I'm using 2,9X9,5 self-tapping pan head screws.

There are 2 sizes of paddles.

This is an Arduino engine sound simulator for RC cars.

Software: https://github.com/TheDIYGuy999/Rc_Engine_Sound

The engine sound is controlled by a standard RC servo / ESC control signal.

Videos:
How to prepare sound files: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-UPb9nRPHV8
First test: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HoMK2IdnbcQ
Mustang V8: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c6SuleJacWg
How to wire: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pPlrx9yVI6E&t=119s

Parts list:

  • 10kOhm trim potentiometer (instead of the both 1k and 10k resistors) for volume adjustment in the mustang video
  • 0.5W, 8 or 16Ohm 55mm speaker
  • Arduino Pro Mini 16MHz, 5V
  • PAM 8403 amplifier module
  • 100uF, 25V electrolytic capacitor for amplifier supply
  • wires and 3 pin dupont connector

Igus bearing hole size is 16mm after PLA shrinkage it fits my 15.8mm Igus bearing perfectly. There is a 1mm gap for clamping onto the bearing so there is pressure applied which is needed for Igus bearings to work properly other wise you will have small amount of wiggle from the bearing on the 8mm smooth rod. Also allows for space on the drive belt side by having a low profile side.

Use M4 bolt and nuts (hole size 4.2mm)

Diagram shown for the standard LM8UU block that the design is based off.
The double Igus bearing block has a 50mm gap to centers (outside holes). This design fits my Anet A8 and also E3D printed hotend.

Designed in Google Sketchup design files included. Please give credit when remixing my files or design.

Printer:

Anet A8

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Print with the block standing on its end (will need a 90 rotation). Support is not required to print in this orientation, the only part that has overhang is the M4 bolt holes and nut capture hole (i printed with support set to 72 so the holes were perfect).

Designed to fit any standard J head or pursa i3 design.
I am using with this design:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2316850

I have adapted it so that it will fit over my "CR10S-Fan-Shroud" https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2806484

Printer Brand:

Creality

Printer:

CR-10S

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

10%

After Printing:

You might have to sand down the inside edges if the fit is too tight.

Original instructions by Caster

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2469518
CR-10 DTI holder for bed alignment by Caster is licensed under the Creative Commons - Attribution license.
http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/

Summary

To make bed leveling quick and accurate I printed a holder for this very cheap but excellent quality DTI.
Link to the DTI which the bracket fits. https://goo.gl/9HYmRr
The DTI is fitted to the holder and pushed on the the fan housing. The code is selected from the SD card and it will first heat up the bed and nozzle to operating temperature (if required) and then home the bed and pause whilst the height is set with a slip of paper between bed and nozzle.
After a delay the Z axis rises and then descends onto the bed and the DTI is set to zero.
After a pause it then moves to each corner in turn and the bed adjusting screw is turned until the DTI reads zero.
It then returns to to the home position, rises and the DTI can be removed ready to print.
I have printed these leveling knob attachments and they make adjustment very easy, no more fumbling around under the bed.
The gcode is here
http://myfordboy.blogspot.co.uk/p/creality-cr-10.html

title: Puzzle-Together Laptop Stand Remix for MSI 17" Laptop GE72MVR 7RG Apache Pro

description.text:
I really loved the idea of the original stand but my MSI Laptop would just slide off at the bottom.

So I made the front more of a hook that holds the front of the laptop and the back a bit longer.

Since I didn't want to waste that much filament my tolerances for the front hook were 1mm, which now is good because I was able to glue an anti-slide-mat to the top that now protects the laptop front top edge from getting scratches when being inserted / taken out.

comments.text: Nice adaptation of the design to fit your laptop! I'd love it if you would also share the bar you made to connect two puzzle stand pieces -- that's a great innovation for saving filament!

author: ForAiur

description.text: CLIP FOR DVRBOX

I wanted a better brush cleaner than a sour cream container so I decided to design one.
My first version was a single water well but realized that I didn't really want two separate water wells one for dirty water and one for clean water so I made a merged one that has 2 wells attached by the brush holder ring.
I was going to put a grid in the bottom to let you clean the brush against but it would be way to hard to clean the settled paint out of it so I went with rings that are 2mm wide and 3mm apart, it works very well and is easy to clean with a bottle brush if needed.
I printed mine out of PETG so I could clean it with hot water without it softening.
If you use this for anything other than acrylic paints I suggest that you print it in a chemical resistant filament.
The clean water well is smaller than the dirty water well as once most of the paint is out of the brush the clean/rinse water doesn't get that dirty that fast.
There are two versions of the clean water well, I made one 1mm smaller around as one of my printers was printing it a little bigger than it should so that took care of that. (the ends of the half moon points were coming out a little too long.)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

solid

Notes:

2 walls and solid infill to make it be a bit more solid.
I actually ended up doing two processes with simplify3d the first one was 3 perimeters and solid infill as the bottom with a single wall did not connect to the infill and stopped at 2.3mm height then went single wall 100% infill just to make it more "solid"
I had some issues with the filament under extruding and leaving miniscule holes in the corners of the crosshatch of the infill add enough of them up and it leaked pretty well. You may want to do an over sized first layer to stop any leaks, also what I did after fixing the filament under extrusion was to change the infill pattern from 45, -45 to 45,0,45,90 to add some vertical infill and it is really water tight now.

title: DJI F450 top cover  and top plate with FPA (water resistant)

description.text: This is a top cover and top plate designed for the DJI450 that protects the quad from damage, and keeps everything tidy. The top plate also provides extra surface area for the user to add more electrical components among other things, and the cover fits snugly over.(((warning, the top plate will cause  problems printing. The problem is that there are small extrusions around each hole that do not allow the plate to lay flat on the bed. Because of this the printer will get jammed up and make a huge mess. The best fix for this is to edit the ipt file and take away the small extrusions that are the cause to the problem.)))

Top Cover with FPV-
1 print with low resolution upsidedown with rafts and support (Makerware)
2 have the part upside down
3 put 7/8" rubber grommet in camera hole
4 use standard board FPV camera
5 push camera head into the rubber grommet
6 place telemetry through the hole in the back, and join it with the antenna on the other side Top plate-
1 print in standard resolution (Maker ware)
2 screw 3d printed top plate over the DJI F450 top plate
How to put the cover on-
1 place the cover over the top plate
2 zip tie cover to arms using tabs (only 2 needed)

comments.text: I just ordered a 3d printer of my own been using the local hobby shops makerbot mini anyway. Is it possible to tilt the camera hole back about 25 degrees? I want to learn how to do this and I know I can I just need to know where to go to learn it. I would like to add a mobius mount on top at the same angle as well.

title: GeBO-Quick - Geared Bowden Extruder with Quick-Release
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
GeBo-Quick

The basic idea behind this extruder is a quick-release mechanism that is operated by turning the knob at the side. Turning it clockwise by 120° will release the filament permanently. Turning it backwards by 120° will re-lock the filament. Further it includes a gear drive with a ration of 3:1. The extruder is symmetrical, so you can position it however you want. Just switch the bowden tube adapter between top and bottom.

Attention

The dimensions in this part are set exactly without taking in account that 3D-printers usally produce smaller holes, i.e. for the 625ZZ bearing the hole is exactly 16 mm. If you print it like this most of the parts are probably to tight. The way I like to do this is to use the horizontal-expansion function of the slicer (that how it is named in cura, the naming in other slicers might differ). For my printer a horizontal-expansion of -0.15 mm gives a nice tight fit without manual post processing. For your printer you might need slightly different setting. Try to find them, it's makes designing stuff much easier and the designs are less printer dependet.

Set-up

After assembly with the instructions in the images above make sure that the knob is screwed on only very lightly and first set your desired tension with the two screws on the side of the extruder (if you use fixed tension you can obviously skip the last part). After that turn the knob and "click" it over several times until it is just slightly lose in the in the filament-tensioned-position and quite tight in the filament-free-position. You will see what I mean when you play around with it. If you over-tightened the knob, so that it is not loose in the initial position anymore, pull it outwards and turn it back.

BOM

  • 2 x 625ZZ bearing
  • 1 x 623ZZ bearing
  • 1 x filament drive gear (MK8 or compatible)
  • 1 x NEMA17 stepper
  • 1 x spring (~ 8x20 mm)
  • 4 x M3 threaded inserts (4x5 mm) (additional inserts for mounting)
  • 4 x M3 nuts
  • 7 x M3x6 mm screws
  • 7 x M3x20 mm screws
  • 1 x M3x10 mm screw
  • 1 x M3x30 mm screw
  • 1 x M5x60 mm screw
  • 2 x M5 washer
  • 1 x M5 nut
  • 1 x Bowden tube adapter (E3D mount)

Thanks

  • Took a lot of inspiration from all the awesome extruders here
  • Gears generated with https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1359815

author: Robot_Jan

description.text:
Note: This design is currently in development, see updates below

mechanical

This model should fit Olympus E510 DSLR camera.

  • Electrical contacts: 6.4mm wide cable lugs (blue color code) should fit (" Push On Blue Male 6.4mm").
  • 8mm barrel plug should screw in.
  • 3.5mm cable hole should fit a second cable (in my case to power a 2nd/external screen).

Printed on Prusa i3 mk2 in PLA (trasparent, cheapest from ebay).

Designed in OpenSCAD.

electrical

The camera expects two Lithium-Ion cells in series, so 7.2V (3-4.2V *2 = 6 - 8.4V). There is space inside this adapter for a voltage regulator (linear or switching) so the whole thing can be supplied by a 12V wall wart.

I put in a LM317 linear voltage regulator with voltage set to 7.0V. Decoupling caps are 4.7uF/50V and 100nF ceramic at input. With 12V input and 0.5A load temperature is still within acceptable range (regulator can be touched without ouch). Peak power consumption up to 2A works without problem (2.2A is typical current limiting point). e510 is defined with 1.6Ah is enough for 650 images (according to CIPA), this means 1600mAh/650 = 2,5mAh per picture. One picture every 30 seconds --> 5,4h with 1600mAh --> 300mA average current consumption.

Don't destroy your camera with incorrect voltage, polarity, surges/spikes etc. !!! (or at least do not blame me ;)

Updates:

  • design finished, print started? Yes! (4.3.2018 9:30 AM)
  • Fits in Olympus e510 mechanically? Yes! (4.3.2018, 11:30 AM)
  • Electrical contacts fit? Yes! (4.3.2018, 11:40 AM)
  • Circuit board fits? Yes! (4.3.2018, 7:30 PM)
  • barrel connector fits? --> hole tiny bit too small (but needs individual adaption depending on type anyway) (8.3.2018, 5:30 PM)
  • camera works / not fried? --> next! (8.3.2018, 5:30 PM)
Laboratory power supply box(DIY)

title: Sannce I21AG Camera Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Sannce I21AG wireless camera is great on Duet Web Control but it is big and the remote pan & tilt capabilities are not needed for 3D print monitoring. It is also big - far bigger than necessary for 3D printing.

This is my solution to that - designed to fit onto my 3D printers (a large delta and a cartesian based on an I3 steel clone).

Strip down the Sannce camera, removing the two stepper motors and all but the front curved section that the camera is screwed to (by the way, both my camera boards only had 1 of the 3 board mounting screws attached - someone was too lazy to do the job properly!).

There is a recess in the back for the speaker and a bit of hot glue holds it securely. Two of the screws from the Sannce are used to hold the camera to the new backplate - the ones with flanges. You will need to drill 2 x 1.5mm holes in the white edges of the camera mounting bit for these screws.

The power cable is fed through the strain relief section before exiting through the hole and then being soldered to a suitable connector or power cable. I did not re-use the USB socket although you may choose to do so.

The WiFi antennae simply clips into the hole on the top of the new back.You will need to carefully remove the coax connector from the PCB and replace it afterwards.

3mm cap screws, washers and nuts are required.

Other parts designed for my printers include:

remixed_from.author: neo777
remixed_from.title: Wanhao i3 Extended Adjustable Tension Extruder Lever

description.text:
Drive block and adjustable tension lever for Wanhao Duplicator i3 v2.1 and other printers with the same setup.

Even if I were able to print with flexible filament with the existing drive blocks, it was always a hassle to load the filament.
This drive block is designed to hug the filament from loading point and onwards. There is simply no way the filament can escape.

Of course I then had to redesign the lever as well to make the parts fit.

This work is inspired by several existing designs (see Remix source files), but I had to re-design it from the group up, making completely new parts (base and lever).
The nub file is not my design. It comes directly from thing:1516255 by dumbcomputers.

UPDATE 2018-03-07
New lever (extarm3_v4)
I found that the pressure on the filament / extruder gear might be a bit high. I've edited the lever so the nub can now go somewhat higher (into the lever). I haven't tested it yet so I'm keeping the old (extarm3_v3) here for now.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 (or 0.2 with adaptive layer hight)

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The drive block prints on its back.
The lever can be printed on its side or with top down (thats how I printed it).

Clean up the parts and make sure the lever fits nicely on the drive block cone. Otherwise sand it down until you get a nice snug fit.

Install a M3-nut in the adjustable arm. You might need some force to get it in. It's a tight fit.

I recommend drilling up the filament tube with a 2mm drill. You can get the filament through without doing so, but I still suggest you open it up a bit.

Install the v-block bearing in its seat. It should more or less snap into place. Fix it with a M3x10 from the back. Make sure the end of the screw is flush with the front of the lever. Otherwise you won't be able to fit the heatsink properly. There is plenty of room for the screw head between lever and drive block.

Make sure the bearing can rotate freely. Otherwise take it out and clean up the print some more.

Installation onto extruder is the same as for the original drive block.

title: Peon 230 Arm V1 mixed with Prop Guard - single print

description.text:
Firstly I'd like to say I'm fairly new to this community and I love all the work you guys put in, this is my first quad so I'm still very much a beginner - I hope to not need prop guards for long! Thanks Tech2c - without you I'd have not gotten into this at all! (And in actuality if it weren't for the RClifeon youtube channel I'd have not found this when I did)

So I'm currently playing about with the standard prop gaurd by IlanF printed in TPU so this is not fully flight tested yet

But I didn't like the idea of having the motor mounting bolts having to be longer so thought it might be nice to have the arms with an integrated guard - keeping weight to a minimum as well - so have merged the two designs in fusion 360.

While I was on with it have enlarged the centre of the motor mount to 6.5mm as the original Peon arms would foul on my motors (4X Racerstar Racing Edition 1806 BR1806 2280KV 1-3S Brushless Motor CW/CCW For 250 260 RC Drone FPV Racing) so I would always have to drill them out - will save me a job now

UPDATE 10/03/2018 - Fly just great, had a huge crash before i remembered to take a pic hence one of the bumpers is missing an arm but still working fine (got tangled up in a tall sycamore and fell over 30ft upside-down - had to replace the top plate also - hey thats why we love 3d printing though!

author: LKM

title: Airfoil used for laminar air flow inside windtunnel

description.text: Research involves development of experiments to prove or disprove a hypothesis. Experiment heavily depend on isolating the variable in question, keeping any other factors constant. The Airfoil is designed for keeping the air flowing inside a windtunnel to be laminar. This means we can reduce errors due to the turbulent nature of the air flow. Thus giving chance to study the fundamental effects of the airflow over object in study (e.g water droplet, crystal structure , etc)
The object is printed in two pieces. One is a mirror image of the first. Later the pieces where glued together using acetone.

description.text:
Anet A8 top back Spool Holder

This is for the ANET A8, i designed this spool holder for my 3d printer

Minimal design but very resistant

I don't like to use all my filament to print stupid 3d printer components so I decided to build my own by optimizing the structure in order to obtain the maximum strenght with a very small amount of PLA. Even if the design seems to be relatively fragile, it's design and simulated to hold >4X the weight of a single spool.
Also to keep the design simple i decided to remove the bearings which are common in holders like that beacuse the screw lying directly on the support perform very well also without spending moneys with bearings.

title: 2x Speedlight to Neewer Softbox (circular studio mount)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I created this because I got some Neewer Softboxes for free and had no way to use them with a speedlight. You can attach two full-sized speedlights to the vertical bracket using collared 1/4-20 to coldshoe adapters from amazon with the 1/4-20 end screwed into the coldshoe stand that came with your flash.

https://www.amazon.com/Fotasy-SCX2-Adapter-Premier-Cleaning/dp/B00HPAPFNU/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1520155578&sr=8-1&keywords=1%2F4-20+to+hotshoe

I included the sketchup document in case you wanted to design it for another circular studio light system such as the profoto lineup.

This is a first edition and was created using the measurements taken from a pair of yongnuo 600-ex-rt flashes therefore, if you have any other flash your results may vary. I recommend measuring the length of your flash and comparing it to the length of this bracket to determine whether your flash will be close enough/fit inside.

description.text:
This is a Stevenson Screen meteorological shelter for enclosing an outdoor weather station.

It's been designed to fit on to 40mm push fit waste pipe (which is very cheap and easy to get). It's a very tight fit to ensure it doesn't come off. You will need at least the base and the top. You can have as many middle parts as you like. Each layer needs 3 M3 self tapping screws between 8 and 12mm in length, and will need to be assembled from the top down. I recommend pushing the base on the pipe before screwing on the rest of the layers.

While not compulsory, rounding out the holes in the posts with a 2.5mm drill bit will make screwing everything in easier.

I've printed mine off in white PETG

author: chris3004

title: Wanhao Duplicator 7 Mask Creation Toolset
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
One of the issues people are encountering when printing using an LCD-based 3D printer, such as Wanhao Duplicator 7, is the need for a mask, if the entire build plate area is to be used. This is because no matter of light source is used, there are differences in light intensity across the printing area. If these are not compensated for, there may be issues with the print, like over or under exposure, or worse the print may fail at all.
For compensation a mask is to be used. A mask is an image, of the size of the LCD screen, that will be darker in the more illuminated areas and lighter in the less illuminated area. Ideally, if only this image will be displayed on the LCD, the result will be that each pixel will be let the same amount of light to pass through, thus resulting in an uniform illumination of the resin.
Obtaining a mask is not a trivial think though. Basically, two different methods where devised by communities around different 3D printer models.
One is based on taking a picture of the LCD through a diffusing screen (such as a piece of paper), and graphically processing the image to basically "invert" the image.
The other will measure the light across the entire LCD screen, using a sensor, then generate an image that will do the job. This may sound a bit magically and too technically perhaps for most users. Therefore, any implementation of the method should be simply enough and use, if possible, readily available software applications that one may have already installed or at least can be easily installed and used.
The toolset proposed here is composed of two parts.
The hardware part is a made of parts printed using a FDM/FFF 3D printer. The actual measurement part is a light sensor, that could be basically anything that can transform light into something electrically measurable. My installation uses a photoresistor which resistance value is measured by a regular multimeter instrument.
The software part is based on a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet where the measured values are entered and the "brut" mask is generated as an array of grey-shaded cells. This is further processed into a smooth grey-gradient image that is the actual mask.
The thing as is can be used for Wanhao Duplicator 7, but one may get inspired and adapt it to other LCD-based (or even projector-based) 3D printers.

Update history
04.03.2018

  • thing created, with summary
  • stl models for hardware part uploaded

comments.text: Wich software did you use and wich resistor? or is every resistor usefull?

comments.text:
Working on an Excel spreadsheet and an workflow to get the mask done with simple software tools.
Any photoresistor will work, but the more digits you can get with your multimeter the better the accuracy of the mask.

Upcycle your used glass jars with this decorative cloth covered looking lid design!

I originally designed this thing to use with a common 500g nutella jar, but added a simple openScad script to enable customizing for preserving jars with twist-off lids. The basic features of the script are:

  • Customizable diameter and height
  • Coin slot feature for creating a custom money savings box
  • Hole pattern feature for creating a salt/pepper shaker or to use with a straw

I added the files, I used to print the lids you can see in the pictures. You can use and scale them or create your own usiong openScad and the customizer (unfortunately the thingiverse customizer will not work, because I'm using the import command ;-)

I designed this thing in Blender using the cloth physics simulation. You can find the simulation in the .blend file.

Blender cloth physics simulation

You can make this a little simpler.
Print a flat sheet using 1 or two layers.
Place sheet over the opening of the vessel.

Use the lid / similar sized "top" to press the warm sheet into shape , leave in place to cool ( and shrink )

title: SkyWatcher HEQ5 clutch lever stop repair

description.text:
SkyWatcher HEQ5 clutch lever stop repair.

I got myself a second-hand HEQ5 that visibly fell to the ground, resulting in an broken DEC clutch lever stop.

It doesn't look like much but is a real pain as the lever tends to obstruct the rotation of the DEC axis.

Print it plain (100% infill), upside-down with supports underneath.
The RA (flat) model can be printed on its flat bottom without any supports.

Use an M4 grub screw to secure it to the mount.

title: Chess set storage and transport cases

description.text:
These cases are a storage and transport solution for my 3D printed Dubrovnik-style chess set.

You can buy the STL files for the chess pieces here.

This download includes the files for the three cases and lids, and the Pawn and King chess pieces so you can try printing them before you buy the complete set.

All the pawns fit in one box, and the rest of the large pieces fit into two specially designed boxes with offset floors so that their tops are level. A felt-lined lid presses onto the tops of the pieces and is held in place by rubber-bands. This way the pieces are secured and do not rattle or move around inside the case during transport. The bases are embossed with the symbols for each piece to enable correct placement. Parallel tabs on the lids and bases keep the rubber-bands aligned.

If using wood-filament for the lids, as shown here, slow your print speed slightly and print at 200°C.

Print onto a glass bed to achieve a glossy top for your lids.

Felt lining

Cut squares of felt to fit inside the lids and glue them in place with PVA glue. This allows the pieces to be secured by pressure from the lid.

title: Bedside Watch Stand With Cufflink Drawer

description.text:
I printed the parts with a flat face on the table with the axis of the oval vertical so there is no support needed for the stand and only support needed inside the drawer. So the only post printing operations are getting the support out of the drawer and a little scraping to remove the bit of squish where the inside of the oval was on the bed to allow the drawer to slide in.
This works best with the watch strap closed. If you need the item bigger or smaller just scale in the slicer. I just scaled in 2 planes, the 2 that do not affect the length the watch slides on to. I found I needed to scale less than I guessed.
Drawn in Fusion 360. I made one I downloaded and it was a bit flimsy and bendy in use so I drew this one to be rock solid. The drawer occured to me as an after thought.

remixed_from.title: Mini Flame Wheel Style Quadcopter frame.

description.text:
This is a remixed version of the DJI Flamewheel Flame Quad.
I have included three sets of arms that will allow you to print a 220mm, 250mm or 280mm variant.

I have also added slotted motor mounts to allow motors with bolt holes between 16mm and 19mm diameter to be mounted. Just thought this would give greater flexibility in motor choice.

Additionally there are three versions of landing gear, a larger set to allow for a gopro to be mounted underneath, a smaller set to just keep the props out of rough landing surfaces.
These are intentionally mounted to the bottom plate and are weaker at the top of the arms as a sacrificial part in a crash to absorb impact rather than transferring it back to the body or arms.
The third set is an extra small arm-mounted version to give a small amount of clearance with minimal weight.

You will need the following hardware to assemble the frame:
4 - M3 x 35mm
8 - M3 x 15mm
12 - M3 locknuts

description.text:
This is a large old fashioned barn pulley.

It's for decorative purposes such as retro pendant lights or washing lines that need a vintage looking pulley. The pulley takes large rope or cable up to 25mm / 1 inch in diameter.

The overall size is 215mm high, 200mm wide, with a pulley size of 160mm diameter (about 6-1/4" round). Parts will comfortably print on a 200 x 200mm bed - just rotate the side pieces a little so they print on the diagonal.

As well as the printed parts, you'll need some nuts, bolts and washers:

  • 2 x 5mm x 50mm pan head bolts for the side spacers
  • 1 x 8mm x 50mm pan head bolt for the top hangar
    plus washers and nyloc nuts.

If you choose to print the center pulley in two halves as I did, it can be glued and held together with 5 x 3mm x 18mm screws.

Its the first new thing I've posted for a couple of years so do hope you enjoy! Solidworks files are included - go nuts.

author: Marcus24

print_settings.Notes:: Filament consumption

description.text:
This is my IKEA LACK 3D printer enclosure.
It makes use of the popular IKEA LACK table and turns two of them into a nice 3D printer enclosure to be able to print materials that would otherwise be difficult to print.

I decided to do my own enclosure since most others I found didnt have enough height to place a concrete paver in it without having the filament bent or even snap when printing tall objects.

The stl files are designed with tolerances in mind. I discovered my IKEA LACK legs werent that square as they should be and the usual tolerances when 3D printing add the rest to the mix. So even if you don't achieve absolute dimensional accuracy the parts will usually fit.

One thing to keep in mind: I did not yet complete the sides and the front door. This will be next and I will update this thing as soon as possible.

Changelog
2018-03-11 - Finally had the time to print the modified stl files and check if they work as expected. Indeed, the fix I introduced into the Middle Spacers works. My LACK enclosure sides are now pretty much square (444mmx585mm). Time to order polycarbonate panels :-).

2018-03-08 - Discovered another tolerance problem. When printing the Middle Spacers the distance between the legs on the lower and upper side showed a difference of 2mm. This would result in the sides/door being trapezoid. I also made the holes for the brass inserts a bit wider and deeper, as suggested by SuperRoach.

2018-03-07 - Changed the way the leg extensions are mounted to the top LACK legs. BOM and assembly manual updated accordingly. I discovered the LACKs leg pressboard material gets damaged quickly if you unscrew the leg extensions later on.

2018-03-05 - Fixed small missalignment of the holes in all "Middle Spacer" parts. The hole for the woodscrew that connects the leg to the table was not centered.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.32mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Printing the parts is relatively straight forward. I would suggest to print all the parts in PETG since I discovered when printing this in PLA the joints are making squeaking noises due to the vibrations of the printer.

Print settings:
Layer height: 0.32mm
Base layers: 5
Top layers: 5
Outlines/Perimeter shells: 5 (this is important since the thread inserts will need some material to melt in to)
Infill: 15% rectilinear

The preview of the parts shown here does show which side of the part should face towards the printbed.

The following parts do not need support:

  • Leg Extensions
  • Top Spacers FL/FR/RR

The following parts will need support:

  • Middle Spacers FL/FR/RR
  • Spikey Foot

Please see below how often which part needs to be printed:

  • Top Spacer RR - 2x
  • Top Spacer FR - 1x
  • Top Spacer FL - 1x
  • Leg Extension - 4x
  • Spikey Foot - 4x
  • Middle Spacer RR - 2x
  • Middle Spacer FR - 1x
  • Middle Spacer FL - 1x

Filament consumption
You will need around 2 800g spools of filament.

Requirements

BOM without the doors

  • 2x - IKEA LACK table 55x55cm
  • 16x - M4 brass thread inserts
  • 4x - M4x14 countersunk screws
  • 4x - Round countersunk magnets, 20mm diameter, 10mm thick, 5mm countersunk hole
  • 4x - M4 threaded inserts for wood (coarse thread on the outside)
  • 1x - M4 threaded rod (60cm)
  • 4x - M4 nylon stop nuts
  • 2x - M4 square nuts
  • 1x - roll of double sided adhesive tape

Sourcing the magnets is probably the most difficult part of this little project. If you google for "Round Ring Loop Magnet 20 X 10 Mm Counter Sunk Hole 5mm" you should find plenty of options at your location. I got mine from amazon -> https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B010DOWGCC

BOM for the sides and door

  • 12x - M4 knurled nuts
  • 12x - M4x12 setscrews
  • 4x - Macrolon panels in correct size (will update once built)
  • Printed door handles and stuff to make that work (will update once built)

Tools needed:

  • Hacksaw
  • Yard stick
  • Screwdrivers (powertools cordless)
  • 6mm drill bit
  • Scissors
  • Socket key (long) size 7
Step 1 - Decide if you want to shorten the legs of the first IKEA LACK table

The enclosure works by stacking two LACKs on top of each other so the table top of the first LACK becomes the bottom of the enclosure where the printer stands on. In case you are planning to put this on a desk or some workbench you might want to shorten the legs otherwise the whole setup becomes too tall.

Measurement:
The upper LACK enclosure will have a total height of about 63,5cm

  • IKEA LACK - 45cm
  • Leg Extension - 15cm
  • Middle Spacer - 3cm
  • Top Spacer - 0.5cm

The lower LACK table can have a variable length between 5cm (only the table top without legs) and 46.5cm when you decide not to shorten the legs. It is really up to you. However, keep in mind that not having any feet at all will remove the option for a clearance hole in the bottom to route through the power cable.

I did shorten the lower legs to 12cm, this allows me to have a power strip underneath.

So in my case, the complete enclosure has a total height of about 81.5cm.

Step 2 - Install the brass thread inserts

First thing to do is melting in the brass thread inserts. Its basically a simple process. Heat up the insert with a soldering iron and push it gently into the hole in the part until it fits in nicely.
You need to pay attention that the insert is perpendicular to the hole's surface, otherwise the screws for the sides won't fit properly.

It helps to screw in a longer screw and then adjust the insert position so it is positioned properly. After cooling down it sits tight and goes nowhere.

It should look like you see on this picture.

Heat up the insert with a soldering iron Gently melt it into the part It should look like this Step 2 - Install the magnets

After you have the thread inserts in place you can simply push your countersunk magnets in the large holes of your middle and top spacers and secure them using an M4x14 countersunk screws.

When you are finished it should look like this.

Front door magnet installed Step 3 - Attach the spikey feet

Since the legs of the IKEA LACK are actually hollow it is impossible to screw the spikey feet to the legs, if you shortened the legs. Therefore you need to hold them in place with some double sided ahesive tape.

I prepared the spikey feet as seen on the picture and then attached them on the shortened legs.

Inside of the spikey foot Attached spikey cap Step 4 - Attach all the legs

Now it is time to attach the Top Spacers and the Middle Spacers.

For the Top Spacers you just push the woodscrew (included in your LACK) through the hole and screw the leg onto the tabletop. Repeat this for all four legs but pay attention that both magnet spacers face towards the front.

Repeat the same procedure for the Middle Spacers. Slide them over the tabletop's corner and screw them together with leg, pay attention again so the magnet spacers face towards the front. It should look like on the pictures.

Top Spacer tightly mounted Top Spacer magnet side facing towards front Middle Spacer attached Middle Spacer with magnet facing towards front Step 5 - Preparation of the upper LACK legs

Mark the middle on the bottomside of each LACK leg and drill a 6mm diameter hole exactly in the middle of each leg. The hole just needs to be deep enough to have room for the threaded wood inserts. Depending on which ones you have you might need to drill a bit deeper.

Now screw in the threaded inserts, one in each hole.
Attention: because of the cheap material quality you got to get this right the first time, usually the threaded insert won't last if you screw it in and out...

Cleanup the wood chips that are hanging around the hole so you have a nice plane surface.

It should look like this, the threaded insert is properly installed Step 6 - Cut the threaded rod

I got my threaded rod from the hardware store if you want to make things very easy you can usually ask them to cut it right there but it is very easy to cut it at home.

You need to cut 4 rods each of 15cm length.

Mark the rods using some pen, then screw the two M4 square nuts to where your first pencil mark is and lock the nuts.
Now use the hacksaw and cut the rods to length.

On the picture I used a vice, however it works as well holding the rod firmly on a table. Consider using some wooden underlay so you don't damage the surface of the table.

Cutting the rods to length Step 7 - Screw in the rods

Now take your four 15cm rods and screw them into the threaded inserts you prepared. Don't use Loctite or anything like that, you might not get the rod loose again.

Rod inserted into the leg Step 8 - Attach the leg extensions

Now slide the leg extensions over the rods, note the orientation. You want the longer sides facing outwards.

Screw them in place using the M4 nylon stopnuts, but don't overtighten them. They should be hand-tight. The wood crackles lightly, this is OK. Just don't go Hulk...

Leg extension showing the correct orientation Step 9 - Putting it all together

Now stack your IKEA LACK tables on top of each other and you are done with the basic enclosure.
Make sure all the magnets face towards one side, this will be the front door later on.

This is an experimental mechanism for driving cosplay wings from an electric motor. It only has 1 degree of freedom, so the wings can go up and down but won't flap forwards and backwards. Since it uses a worm geared motor, it should be able to hold the wings up indefinitely with no energy cost. It could also be used for a giant mechanical claw or other things that need the same motion.

The type of motor used is a Valeo Type 5 11v heater flap actuator. I'm not sure what model of car it's from but they should be available fairly cheaply on ebay (I've noticed some different shaped axles on these, you may need to customise the main cog depending on which you get). There are a couple of issues using this motor though, first, it uses an automotive connector so will either need a compatible cable or some soldering to connect to it. Secondly, the rotation is limited to a fixed number of degrees by a piece of plastic sticking out of the case that stops the main axle turning outside of that range, but this is fairly easy to mod.

The arms are made from 21.5MM plastic pipe, which should be available at most DIY stores. A few small bolts may also be needed to assemble the parts. The .stl files are designed to minimise overhang for easy printing.

I will add details later where to drill the holes, but you can figure it out from model(hopefully).

title: Hiking Pole Basket (High Colorado Carbon TI)

description.text:
Having lost some of our baskets and not knowing where to get fitting new ones
I went about making some of myself.
Thread pitch is 2,5 mm, it took some trial and error test prints
until the thread would fit to my liking.
It still is a very tight fit which is intended.
I honestly do not know whether our "High Colorado Carbon TI" poles,
which we got at a local outdoor-shop for some 40 bucks, are high quality
or rather cheap ones.
But I learned to like them and think they are worth keeping alive.
No idea whether those baskets will fit other makes or whether all those brands
maybe use the same thread.
Please check on the print settings for stability which prooved to be sufficient.

Made with PETG from these guys https://www.3dpsp.de/ as all my other printer parts.
This stuff turned out to be quite fine to process.
It is quite sturdy, no problems with adhesion at all.
And really nice and brilliant colours for a reasonable price.

UPDATE: Added SCAD file. Should be fairly easy to adapt to other heights/diameters now.

Printable parts for a paper roll mount. Meant for rolls with 22cm outer diameter maximum and at least 4cm inner diameter. The holder is meant to be combined with a wooden rod or aluminium tube of 4cm outer diameter. Length should be chosen by the length of the paper roll + at least 16mm extra to give the roll enough play.
Top bar has 3 holes for M3 screws. Mounting using the two outer screw holes should suffice. Use washers, too.
Warning: if your roll has more than 19cm outer diameter you might not be able to slide the rod/tube in from the sides ( depending on the squishiness of your paper ). The plastic part however ( I used PETG ) should still have enough flex so the rod/tube can be pushed in from the front or below.

Step 1: Getting board dimensions

Removing some sharp edges from the electronics board. Measuring the exact dimensions with a calipher and putting them in Fusion360

Step 2: Making the case

Taking the board design in a new constrution and designed the case and top depending on the board dimensions (tolerances etc.). So adjustments to the board size affected the case size... 1 iteration later ... the final design

title: Hiking Pole fastening clasp (High Colorado Carbon TI)

description.text:
Attention!
If you are one who really uses your poles instead of dragging them behind
you know that this could be a safety issue!
Know what you do and use those clasps on your own risk!

Having broken one of the clamps by tightening to hard in very cold wheather
I had to make one myself.
I immediately liked the look of those colours instead of the black ones
and made more for all our poles.
Please check on the print settings for stability!
We tested them for some time now whithout learning about any downsides.
I dare say, they are even tougher than the original ones (PETG)

I honestly do not know whether our "High Colorado Carbon TI" poles,
which we got at a local outdoor-shop for some 40 bucks, are high quality
or rather cheap ones.
But I learned to like them and think they are worth keeping alive.
No idea whether those clasps will fit to other brands.
Please check on the print settings for stability which prooved to be sufficient.

Made with PETG from these guys https://www.3dpsp.de/ as all my other printer parts.
This stuff turned out to be quite fine to process.
It is quite sturdy, no problems with adhesion at all.
And really nice and brilliant colours for a reasonable price.

Designed as a companion to my CR-10 Direct Drive Conversion available at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2809256

Installation

This is a slide on design.

Pop off the right side end-cap of the top 2020 rail and slide this puppy on. Trim the trim if you desire (mine is just not pressed in on the top edge for now).

Holes are self-tapping.

Use existing thumb screws before mounting to tap, or go balls to the wall and tap while you mount!

There is something magical about 3D sculpting. Watching a sphere turning into a cute Easter Bunny Toy in ZBrush is fascinating. It looks great 3D printed in Fillamentum Wood or PLA.

A support free model. The front paws are at a 30-degree angle - please pay attention to cooling. Also, if scaling down, it's recommended to reduce the layer height.

NB! Wood filament is prone to stringing. And it is hard to put the settings right. Please try our Local Test File "Ears" first before printing the full model. If there is excessive stringing, we would recommend not to print it in wood as missing layers may occur at the very end of the print.

Well another PCB drill press, but with a 24V high Power DC-Motor.

I designed it by myself and I can't tell which material it can drill but there is much power coming from the electric motor. You can set the Speed by turning the potentiometer, it is connected to an speed governor, you can see in the black box.

It has also space for an LED-strip but it's optional.
Here is the parts list with the links:

DC-Motor:
https://de.aliexpress.com/item/1-st-ck-Stabile-775-Micro-High-Speed-Power-Motor-DC12-24V-150-Watt-13000-15000/32848782120.html?spm=a2g0x.search0104.3.8.212442902lSN9C&ws_ab_test=searchweb0_0%2Csearchweb201602_3_10320_10152_10321_10065_10151_10344_10068_10342_10547_10343_10322_10340_10341_10548_10193_10194_10084_10083_10618_10304_10307_10302_10180_5711215_10313_10059_10184_10534_100031_10319_10103_10627_10626_10624_10623_10622_10186_5711315_10621_10620_5722415-10152_10151normal#cfs,searchweb201603_38,ppcSwitch_5&algo_expid=6da06e64-9d82-4c93-9fee-affd005f9053-4&algo_pvid=6da06e64-9d82-4c93-9fee-affd005f9053&transAbTest=ae803_3&priceBeautifyAB=0

description.text:
I wanted a simple way to angle my desktop monitor speakers toward my ears, without adding height. I saw a few other designs on this site, but most seemed to use more plastic than I thought necessary.

My Polk R150s have a 7"x7" base (x10" tall), and these stands hold them at a roughly 13 degree angle. The stand itself is just under 5" wide, so it won't work with narrower speakers.

It's working fine as-is for me, but adding some material to the base or contact points may be worthwhile. There are rubber feet on the back edge of the speakers, which is what keeps them from the slipping backward.

Designed from scratch in Sketchup 2018 - file attached.

I thought about making these to allow for adjustable height (as I think others have done with theirs) but it simply wasn't necessary for me.

description.text:
Hi!

This is the second collection about Conway's Game of Life. 23 Oscillators ready to print.

(See my first collection with 60 files here: Conway's Towers)

The structures generated are called Oscillators as they repeat a pattern after a number os steps.

Lot of oscillators found here: [http://catagolue.appspot.com/home] and in his related Twiter Account @conwaylife

And tons of patterns and all the info about the Conway's Game Of Life in this fantastic site: www.conwaylife.com

23 STLs ready to print and their thumbnails in ZIP file

Nice for decoration or as scenery for tabletop games.

Generated procedurally using [Processing] (www.processing.org) and conversion to STL made with 3D builder (Windows 10 software).
Still developing the software so i eventually publish the sources.

Easy to print, no supports required. See below for some printing tips.

Hope you like it.

Have fun!!

I have lots of different generic motors, and I need them for a couple of projects that involve the Arduino. In order to make the motor less ugly and more capable of being screwed on to something, I made a parametric case, so that I could put in the parameters, and get a case for any of my motors. Then I realized that other people might need a motor case too, so I put it on Thingiverse under public domain. It also comes with 2 example motor case, for the motors shown in the pictures. Also, this is the 2nd parametric design I have made so don't laugh at it.
(It is not physically tested yet, although it has been theoretically tested)

To make a parametric design:
  • Download DC_motor.png and Motor.scad
  • DC_motor.png contains a picture to help explain what each of the parameters mean
  • Plug in your parameters.
  • Print it! (Or do whatever you want with it!)
    • Post any comments or suggestions.

description.text:
When designing this clip I had just broken a similar clip from Thingiverse (the green one in the third photo). The clip must have some flex, and the design with the open middle is supposed to allow for sufficient flex while still holding the poles firmly. The joint in the middle may seem fragile, however I find that using less material in this joint makes for less stress on the joint.

I printed the clip with 100% infill, however I am sure it will work with less. The print time and material used printing with 100% is negligeble anyway: 26 mins and 2.18 meters using FlashForge Finder.

The ski pole clip is meant to be used in pairs. One clip near the top of the pole and one near the lower third of the pole.

author: the_messy_desk

title: Capacitive height sensor with e3d v6 Hotend Clone anet A8
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Adding a capacitive height sensor is so useful when you get bored to setup every time the bed level ;) and honestly, it's so nice to see this cycle before printing, i'm fan!
In addition, this is the good time to add a new hotend with the extruder out of the support, it gives best printing quality and lower collision troubles ;)
Because it was hard me for to find a complete tuto with both hardware and software, i share my full installation, consider this tuto as plug and play if you follow step by step with the same material than me.
I suppose you use like me octoprint to communicate with the printer (mainly for the terminal here)
I choose this sensor to measure height also over a glass.

You follow this tuto at your own risk, i'm not responsible of your errors (if any).

Material to buy:

  • 3D Printer E3D V6 J-head Hotend 1.75mm here
  • Capacitive sensor 18mm here
  • 2x JST-XH 2.54mm Base Female 3 pins here
  • 1 JST-XH 2.54mm Base Female 2 pins here
  • Optional: Raspberry pi here to communicate with the printer, and fully needed for octoprint
  • Optional: Mosfet to protect the board here
  • Optional: Heat Shrink tube to connect properly here

Material to Print (Do it before unmounting your original head ;) )

  • Bowden Extruder Mount here
  • E3d v6 Bowden Print Carriage here using (Print_Carriage_Plate_PROXIMITY_18mm_SENSOR stl and cooling duct from last edit:
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2086437)
  • Optional but recommanded:https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2105040

First thing to do

Flash your mainboard (I suppose you bought the raspberry pi), all the parameters are set with the good values for the support and sensor.

  • Connect the usb printer to the raspberry one
  • install exe to update the mainboard : sudo apt-get install avrdude
  • Copy the .hex i provide to /home/pi/ folder
  • if octoprint is already installed and connected to the pi, stop it:
    sudo service octoprint stop
  • Flash the firmware with skynet and replacing the port ttyUSBXX by yours:
    first check usb port : sudo ls /dev/USB gives a list of ttyUSBXX
    and flash with the command (single line):
    sudo avrdude -p m1284p -c arduino -P /dev/ttyUSBXX -b 57600 -D -U flash:w:SkynetV2.3.2.ino.sanguino.hex:i

If it work, you'll see and writing and reading instruction, and a reboot of the mainboard,
if not check again your wiring.

Restart octoprint service if octoprint was installed and connected:
sudo service octoprint start

Material installation:

  • E3d v6: the fan cable is too short, you need to cut/add cable and use the JST-XH 2.54mm Base Female 2 pins and plug to fan 1 port, the second fan is the original fan you add to the new support as fan 2.
    The 2 thin white cables from hotend are plugged using 1 JST-XH 2.54mm Base Female 3 pins, replacing the port used by the old hot end, hotend power cable are connected to the mosfet or mainboad.(see mosfet diagram)

  • Capacitive sensor:
    The original endstop is unplugged.
    Use 1 JST-XH 2.54mm Base Female 3 to connect following Sensor wiring diagram
    Try to fix the sensor with its bottom 3-4 mm higher than the nozzle
    Manually, move down the head with a small step (careful, there ' s no more endstop now), and check the top light of the sensor bright when you reach 5-10 mm above the bed.
    if not check again the wiring.
    To prevent collision while setting up the auto leveling (i did it several times ;)), move the head to 20mm above the bed and set a new Z0
    Into octoprint terminal:
    'M851 Z0' # reset Z offset to “0”
    'M500' # Save to EEPROM
    'G92 Z0' – This tells the printer that “This is now Z0”
    'M500'

Software:

  • From your slicer, add the following code on start:
    ...
    G28 X0 Y0 ;move X/Y to min endstops
    G28 X28 Y0 ; /* manage the offset from probe to nozzle
    G29 ; Auto Bed Levelling
    ...
    M117 Printing...

  • Initial Auto leveling setup:
    From octoprint terminal:
    1. Preheat Nozzle and Bed
    2. M851 Z0 - reset Z offset to “0”
    3. M500 – Save to EEPROM
    4. G28 – Auto Home (sensor will be centred at this point)
    5. G1 X110 Y110 / (G1 X110 Y135 if you have an A2 with 220x270 bed) - move nozzle to centre
    6. Move Nozzle down to the correct gap (about the thickness of a4 paper)
    7. G92 Z0 – This tells the printer that “This is now Z0”
    8. G30 X110 Y110/ (G30 X110 Y135 if you have an A2 with 220x270 bed)
      It tests the trigger distance and displays the offset on octoprint terminal as a positive value e.g Z2.1
    9. M851 Z (eg. M851 Z-2.1)
    10. M500 – Save to EEPROM
    11. Don't forget G29 After the G28 in your start g code to activate auto bed levelling.

Change Bed support

From now, you can remove your existing height system control and replace it with a fixed support, i use this one with my glass: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2273270

The X-Axis Cable Chain is very usefull to group all cables and give a nice aspect to the anet, with both sensor and cable chain, 'Elle a tout d'une grande' as we say in france ;)
(looks like a real pro printer, and even better according to me ;))

Enjoy ;)

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Hi,
Actually i setup the height for the PLA temperature.
Then when i print with abs, i adjust the height with a cura plugin named Zoffset.(abs need nozzle down as u surely know)
When the measure is really bad (happens once a mounth max), i setup again the initial heigh sensor.
But honestly, compare to manual handling, there's no doubt, i adopt my capacitive sensor which gives me really good print, both for PLA and ABS.
With indictive, you don"t need at all the setup the height sometimes? how to you manage both pla and abs working height?
comments.author: rcaridade

comments.text:
I don't need to adjust the height any more.
I used the same value in "M851 Z-2.90", the system works very well for ABS and PLA.
The inductive sensors don't change much with heat so I don't need to adjust it.
I print PLA with bed 60º and ABS with bed 95º.
My indictive sensor is LJ18A3-8-Z/BX-5V, the capacitive that I used before is LJC18A3-H-Z/BX.

author: Rade0041

description.text:
This design is inspired by the awesome MasterSpool concept by RickRap https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2769823. It uses roughly 20 percent less material and prints 15 % faster than RichRaps MasterSpool V4 while maintaining more stability than is needed.
I also increased the number of storage options for the filament end.
It can be used with 1.75 mm, 2.84 mm and 3 mm filaments. I designed it for optimal print quality with 0.4 mm and 0.6 mm nozzles and layer heights of 0.2 mm and 0.3 mm.

Let me know if you have ideas on how to improve the design.

Print setting recommendations:
Nozzle Diameter / Extrusion Width
0.4 mm or 0.6 mm

Outline / Perimeter Shells
0.4 mm Nozzle -> 3 Shells or 1.2 mm
0.6 mm Nozzle -> 2 Shells or 1.2 mm

Layer Height
0.2 mm, 0.3 mm

Infill
10 % Rectilinear or 20 % Grid

Support
no support material needed

I remixed my cable slitter again. Last time I promise.

I added a blade cover so only about half of the razor blade is exposed. It’s a little safer now.

I had to edit the bottom half a little to accept the longer guard so I don’t think that R1 and R2 are interchangeable.

I have printed a lot of the R1’s. Depending on the filament, some of the screws get bound up in the threads. I have sanded the threads, filed the groves deeper, applied mineral oil.

I scaled the screw down in the x and y axis, leaving the z axis alone so the threads will still line up. I made three screws, original, -10%, and -20%. Depending on your filament and printer set up, one of these should work.

There is a tiny slot that gets fused back together (on my printers anyway) and it should be cut apart with a razor blade. It is located on the opposite side of the screw, in the front, 5mm up from the base. It makes a locking tab for the blade. You can see it in Thingiview.

Use an 8-32X3/4 for the hinge bolt
Wrap a rubber band around it for an automatic tensioner!
This also holds it closed, making it safe to throw in your tool box so you do not get cut up digging for it later.

So far I have only printed this in PETG, 235 Nozzle, 70 bed, 0.2 layer, 50% infill

description.text: 1590A passthrough mod holder, mount it anywhere using double sided tape.

This is a very simply yet effective tool tidy to keep beside you whilst you are working on things. You can keep magnifiers in there, screwdrivers, Scalpels and there is a little tray on the front for you to put the screws you have removed from an object making it easier to find them when putting it back together.

Reasoning...

I made this because I always have about 10 tools I always use, it makes sense to keep them together tidy :)

SINCE PRINTING:...
Ok I have now printed and I'm using it. I will say its a big help in just keeping my workspace tidy. There is also lots of room for remixing too and with a little imagination it can probably become a hundred times more efficient. Please let me know what you think and also maybe answer these questions...

1) If you could change one thing, what would it be and why?

2) If you would add something what would it be?

It was designed in FUSION3D and Im happy to pass on any files needed.

Regards and happy Printing :)

Ideas...

This can be pimped up with maybe a long rod with a light and magnifier on and possible a usb socket for 5v of power.... It can have attachments with different screw heads in etc...

remixed_from.author: pmeyer
remixed_from.title: prusa i3 mk3 PSU adapter for MeanWell 350

description.text:
I didn't particularly like the PSU cover part from pmeyer's Prusa i3 MK3 PSU adapter... it's kinda large, making connecting the wires difficult, and blocks some of the front vents. So I made a new one.

This is intended for the switch and power inlet that come with the Prusa i3 MK3, but you could probably find those parts and use this in your own projects. Also, this doesn't mount to the printer directly, but it works nicely with the brace from pmeyer's adapter.

Note that it is a tight fit... if the dimensional accuracy of your printer is at all in question, you'll want to increase the size slightly, preferably in OpenSCAD but scaling in your slicer might work.

comments.text: Cool!  To save me diffing the scad file, what did you change?  The lowered edge over the switch/plugs is obvious (and a good move).  Which wires did you have difficulty connecting, and how did you fix that issue?
comments.author: pmeyer

comments.text: A diff won't help you, mine's a rewrite with a few bits copied. The overall height is shorter (81 vs 100mm) and the left side wall is thinner (not for any particular reason, I just saw no particular reason to make it thicker than the others). The switch is a little higher and to the right, making it closer to the screw terminal for the line input.
comments.author: pmeyer

comments.text: Makes sense.  All my sizing was direct measurement off the original Prusa base, no optimization for the Meanwell (once I had it printed and it worked, I was done!).   I agree the AC wires were a bit tight, but they did make it for me.
comments.author: FourOhFour

comments.text: I wonder if there's some variation in wire length... the power wires going to the electronics were too short (but easy enough to replace) but the power panic line reaches fine... thankfully, I didn't want to either resolder it or find the right parts to make an extension.

description.text: Only fill some holes for print in HIPS, and get more reinforce

If you want to shutdown the power supply after a print, this device can help you.

All your printer need to do is switching a pin to ground (the input is idle high and designed to handle 3,3v for use on a raspberry Pi), when finished.

To Re enable the power supply push the button.

The device will wait 120s before cutting the power supply, while this time the LED is blinking and you can abort the process, by pressing the abort button.

Pressing the abort button for 3s while waiting for print finished will instantaneous switch the power off

The gehaeuse_ausschaltbox.scad is just to give you a overview do not print this.

To Rebuild this you need to be able to

  • program a AT-Tiny85 (source included)
  • soldering a circuit
  • handle high Voltage (230V in Germany) (!! Attention!! doing wrong things can kill you !!)

Buy List :

  • 2* bistable relays 5V
  • 1* ATTiny85
  • 2* switches (low voltage)
  • 1* switch (high voltage)
  • a LED
  • resistors (5 10kOhm, 1 100kOhm, 1* 470Ohm)
  • capacitor (3* 100nF)
  • C-Mos 2N7000 (3-times)
  • 5* M3 nut
  • 5* M3x12 screw

All parts where bought on www.Reichelt.de, if you wish i can give the exact ordering numbers.

Building this thing:
Use EAGLE to open the .brd and .sch file -> build your PCB
Configure the fuse-bits of the AT-Tiny as shown in the screenshoot
Use avg-gcc to compile (main.c) and a isp-programmer to flash the AT-Tiny (no arduino, support)
Print the chase, mount everything together and connect it to your printer in this order

socket -> Device -> device power station / printer

Push the button to start and have fun g.

title: Dolce Gusto Wall Capsule Dispenser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a wall mounted Dolce Gusto capsule dispenser. The wall fixation is intended to be hot glued to avoid making any hole and it is able to hold up to 7 capsules.

I designed it to save the maximum filament and printing time. It only requires about 35 grams and two hours to be printed (depending on parameters) which is much less than others found.

I also upload three versions with capsule identification in spanish, let me know if you need some other labels and I will try to upload it.

It need bed support for the first part as shown in pictures. Without furhter supports some bridging is noticeable but you can sand it or decrease the layer height. My printer settings are:

  • 0.3 Layer height.
  • PLA
  • 60 mm/s of printing speed
  • Bed supports
  • 2 walls
  • 50 % Infill (this won't change the printing speed a lot since it only affects the main column and the bottom plate).

Hope you enjoy guys!

Regards.

Leberkässemmel

Made in Fusion 360.

Just a simple clip that will catch on the Z axis screw holes if the head starts dropping after a print or just doesn't want to stay up. I got tired of this happening, I had the nozzle melt a few prints and messed up a few others just by the weight of the head by falling after the print was done so I thought I'd try and think up something.

It can be mounted on top or underneath the X axis (or both) on the left side only. The head will hit it on the right side. I only keep it clipped back when starting a print then release it after it starts.Depending on your plastic if you keep it clipped back it may stay that way when you want to release it.

I tried to keep this small enough and not very strong so it'll break before it breaks anything on your machine. It's only indented to stop it from a free fall.

I'm still playing around with this a little so it could change. I've only done one print with it so far so I'm sure I'll find something I need to tweak, or maybe I'll find out it's crap and do something completely different.
